questions.text: A patient with HIV who is currently on antiretroviral therapy consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Considering potential drug interactions, which of the following TB drugs should be changed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Rifampicin is a potent enzyme inducer that significantly increases the metabolism of several drugs, including non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) like nevirapine. When used together, rifampicin accelerates the metabolism of nevirapine, reducing its efficacy in treating HIV. This interaction can lead to subtherapeutic levels of nevirapine, thereby compromising the effectiveness of the antiretroviral therapy.

 

In patients with HIV who are on nevirapine-based antiretroviral therapy, rifampicin is usually substituted with rifabutin. Rifabutin has a similar efficacy against tuberculosis but with a lesser degree of enzyme induction, making it a safer option in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is generally safe to use in patients on antiretroviral therapy, as it does not significantly interact with most HIV medications.

 

Option C. Ethambutol: Ethambutol does not have significant interactions with antiretroviral drugs and is safe to use in this patient population.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, also does not interact significantly with antiretroviral therapy and is not the drug that needs to be changed in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV and TB cotreatment:

 

  • If a person is on the TLE regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, efavirenz), it does not interact with rifampicin. The regimen can continue unchanged even if rifampicin is given.
  • If the person is on the TLD regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, dolutegravir), the dose of dolutegravir should be doubled when rifampicin is used, while the rest of the regimen remains the same.
  • If the person is taking a protease inhibitor or nevirapine, rifampicin should be avoided. Instead, rifampicin should be replaced with rifabutin.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration is shown. Identify the pathology. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Testicular torsion

 

The correct answer is Testicular torsion. Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord, which supplies blood to the testicle, becomes twisted, cutting off the blood supply. This condition presents with acute scrotal pain and is a surgical emergency. The intra-operative image shows a discolored and non-viable testis, which is characteristic of testicular torsion. Exploration in such cases is mandatory to assess the viability of the testis and to perform detorsion or orchiectomy if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsion of testicular appendage: Torsion of the testicular appendage, a small vestigial remnant located at the superior pole of the testis, is a self-limiting condition and does not usually necessitate surgical exploration. The testis in such cases remains normal, and the main feature is localized pain without the full testicular involvement seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Torsion of both: It is highly unlikely for both the testis and the appendage to undergo torsion simultaneously as they are separate anatomical structures. Thus, the option of torsion of both is not realistic.

 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: A testicular hematoma would present as swelling due to bleeding within the testicular parenchyma or surrounding tissue, often following trauma. The appearance would not match the twisted and non-viable look of the testis shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion presents as acute testicular pain and requires urgent surgical intervention. The characteristic appearance on exploration includes a discolored, possibly non-viable testis due to the loss of blood supply.

choices.text: Occurs due to saponification of fats

questions.text: Which of these statements is true for Adipocere change after death? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occurs due to saponification of fats

 

Adipocere formation, also known as saponification, is a postmortem change characterized by the conversion of body fat into a waxy substance called adipocere. This process occurs due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats, often in the presence of moisture and certain enzymes. Adipocere is most commonly formed in warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions, but not in extremely high temperatures or cold temperatures.

 

The formation of adipocere is an enzymatic process where body fats are broken down into fatty acids, which then combine with calcium ions to form soap-like compounds. This saponification process helps preserve the body tissues, preventing further decay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs in very high temperature: This option is incorrect because adipocere formation does not require very high temperatures. High temperatures favor mummification by accelerating dehydration rather than promoting saponification.

 

Option B. Occurs in cold temperature: Adipocere formation is less likely in cold conditions, as the enzymatic processes required for saponification are slowed down in low temperatures.

 

Option C. Occurs immediately after death: This is incorrect because adipocere formation takes time and does not occur immediately after death. The process can take weeks to months depending on environmental conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipocere formation after death occurs due to the saponification of fats through an enzymatic process, primarily under warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse and a loud P2 on auscultation. Upon examination of the Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP), which finding is most likely to be observed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absent a wave

 

An irregularly irregular pulse suggests atrial fibrillation, a common cardiac arrhythmia characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions. In atrial fibrillation, the atria do not contract effectively, leading to the absence of the a wave in the Jugular Venous Pulse (JVP). The a wave corresponds to atrial contraction, which is missing in atrial fibrillation because the atria are quivering rather than contracting.

 

Although a loud P2 suggests pulmonary hypertension, which might otherwise be associated with a prominent a wave, the presence of atrial fibrillation supersedes this. In atrial fibrillation, the primary finding in the JVP will always be an absent a wave due to the lack of effective atrial contractions, regardless of any concurrent conditions like pulmonary hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves occur when the right atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, typically seen in complete heart block, not in atrial fibrillation.

 

Option C. Rapid x descent: Rapid x descent is seen in conditions with reduced atrial filling pressures, such as constrictive pericarditis or tamponade. It is not specifically related to atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Rapid y descent: Rapid y descent is seen in conditions like constrictive pericarditis or tricuspid regurgitation, reflecting rapid ventricular filling. It is not characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the key JVP finding is the absence of the a wave due to the lack of effective atrial contraction. This is one of the classic "four no's" associated with atrial fibrillation: no a wave in the JVP, no P wave on ECG, no pre-systolic accentuation in mitral stenosis, and no S4 heart sound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

The patient described in the question is suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). BDD is a mental health condition characterized by an excessive preoccupation with an imagined defect in appearance, or if a minor physical anomaly is present, the person's concern is markedly excessive. Patients often have poor or absent insight, believing firmly in the existence of their perceived defects.

 

The standard treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (DOC) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Even when a patient's insight is at a delusional level, SSRIs remain the first-line pharmacological treatment, as they help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with the disorder. In this case, SSRIs would be the best management option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioural therapy: While behavioral therapy might offer some benefits, the specific first-line treatment for BDD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which targets the distorted beliefs about appearance directly. The term "Behavioral Therapy" is broad and less specific, making SSRIs a more targeted choice.

 

Option C. Atypical antipsychotics: These medications are not considered first-line treatment for BDD. They may be used as adjuncts in severe cases where delusional beliefs persist despite SSRIs, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Allow her for surgery: Surgery is not a recommended treatment for BDD as it does not address the underlying psychiatric condition and often worsens the patient's mental health state by reinforcing their preoccupation with appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

 

The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the rapid onset of painful urethral discharge are highly indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal urethritis typically presents with dysuria (painful urination) and a purulent (pus-like) discharge from the urethra.

 

The treatment of choice for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This treatment is preferred due to its efficacy in eradicating the infection and its convenience as a single-dose therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 2 weeks: Doxycycline is typically used for treating chlamydial infections, which can co-occur with gonorrhea but is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea itself. Additionally, a two-week course is usually prescribed for chlamydia, not gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Benzathine Penicillin: Benzathine Penicillin is primarily used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhea. Syphilis and gonorrhea are different sexually transmitted infections with distinct treatments.

 

Option D. Azithromycin 1 gm stat: Azithromycin can be used in the treatment of chlamydial infections, often alongside treatment for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection. However, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea when given alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and something coming out of the vagina. Her last childbirth was 10 years back. On bimanual palpation, the uterus is palpable. On examination, the cervix admits 1 finger, and the following is seen. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroid polyp

 

The clinical presentation, including heavy menstrual bleeding, the presence of a vaginal mass, and the fact that the uterus is palpable on bimanual examination, strongly suggests a fibroid polyp. A fibroid polyp is a type of submucosal fibroid that protrudes into the uterine cavity and may extend through the cervix into the vagina. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, including intermenstrual bleeding, due to the exposed surface of the polyp that can easily get eroded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenomyoma: This is incorrect. Adenomyoma, a localized form of adenomyosis, typically presents similarly to fibroids but does not cause a vaginal mass. The uterus would also be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open to admit a finger.

 

Option C. Intramural fibroid: This is incorrect. Intramural fibroids grow within the muscular wall of the uterus and do not typically protrude through the cervix to present as a vaginal mass. The uterus would be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open.

 

Option D. Inversion: This is incorrect. Uterine inversion usually occurs postpartum, often immediately after childbirth, or it can present as a chronic condition that began after a previous childbirth. In inversion, the uterus is typically not palpable on bimanual examination because it has turned inside out. The cervix would not admit a finger as the entire uterus is inside out, blocking access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fibroid polyp presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, a palpable uterus on bimanual examination, and a protruding mass in the vagina due to the fibroid extending through the cervix

questions.text: What does ‘H’ indicate in a patient presenting with a history of EHEC O157:H7? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flagella

 

In the nomenclature of bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli (E. coli) strains like EHEC O157, the ‘H’ antigen refers to the flagellar antigen. Flagella are whip-like structures that allow bacteria to be motile. The ‘O’ antigen represents the somatic (cell wall) antigen, which is associated with the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer of the bacterial cell wall. Therefore, the ‘H’ antigen is specifically linked to flagella, which is crucial for bacterial motility and plays a role in pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capsule: The capsule is a polysaccharide layer that surrounds some bacterial cells, providing protection against the host immune system. It is not related to the ‘H’ antigen.

 

Option B. Fimbriae: Fimbriae are short, hair-like structures on the bacterial surface that assist in adherence to surfaces and are not related to the ‘H’ antigen. They are different from flagella and do not contribute to motility.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharide: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and is associated with the ‘O’ antigen, not the ‘H’ antigen. It plays a significant role in the immune response but is unrelated to bacterial motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bacterial antigen classification, the ‘H’ antigen corresponds to flagella, which are essential for motility.

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

 

The images depict subglottic stenosis, which is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation. This condition results from the high-pressure cuff of the endotracheal tube irritating the mucosa beneath the glottis. The Cotton Meyer classification system is used to stage subglottic stenosis based on the degree of airway narrowing:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radkowski: This staging system is used for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), not subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C. AJCC: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for categorizing the extent of cancers, specifically focusing on tumor size (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M). It is not relevant for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing

 

  • Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)

questions.text: An infant of 3 months presents with recurrent severe infections, including pneumonia, chronic diarrhea, and oral candidiasis. He has an absence of thymic shadow on chest X-ray. Laboratory tests reveal very low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent severe infections, absence of thymic shadow, and low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA) are indicative of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

SCID is characterized by a profound deficiency in both T and B cell function, leading to a high susceptibility to infections. ADA deficiency is one of the causes of SCID, resulting in the accumulation of toxic metabolites that damage immune cells.

 

The absence of a thymic shadow on X-ray indicates a lack of T cell development, a hallmark of SCID.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-linked agammaglobulinemia: This condition is due to a defect in the B cell tyrosine kinase gene, leading to an absence of B cells but not T cells. It primarily affects boys and presents with recurrent bacterial infections but not the absence of a thymic shadow or ADA deficiency.

 

Option B. Hyper-IgE syndrome: Also known as Job's syndrome, this condition is associated with elevated IgE levels, recurrent infections, and abnormal dentition. It does not involve the absence of the thymic shadow or low ADA levels.

 

Option D. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): CVID involves B cell maturation defects, leading to reduced antibody production. It does not present with ADA deficiency or thymic shadow absence. Both males and females are equally affected, and the condition is usually diagnosed later in childhood or adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is characterized by recurrent severe infections, absence of thymic shadow, and very low levels of adenosine deaminase, highlighting defects in both T and B cell function.

choices.text: Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

questions.text: A 57-year-old person completed his treatment of leprosy. Two years later, he presents with a punched-out painless ulcer on his sole. What is the next best step in the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

 

The patient is presenting with a chronic trophic ulcer, which is a common complication in patients with leprosy, particularly after the disease has been treated and the bacteria eradicated.

 

Trophic ulcers arise due to the loss of sensation (neuropathy) and autonomic disturbances leading to dry, cracked skin that is prone to injury. The patient does not feel pain, which allows the ulcer to become large and deep over time.

 

The correct management involves reducing pressure on the affected area to allow healing. This can be achieved by advising the patient to bear less weight on the affected foot and using a plaster cast or a total contact cast, which redistributes weight and protects the ulcer from further trauma.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Plantar ulceration is a common complication in lepromatous leprosy, often occurring even after the disease is arrested. Progressive fibrosis of nerves leads to 'glove and stocking' anesthesia, with loss of sensation in the limbs, particularly the plantar aspect of the foot.
  • This condition is one of the most frequent impairments in leprosy, reported in 21% to 63% of newly reported cases. The combination of loss of touch and pain, along with foot deformity, causes disproportionate weight distribution on the sole of the foot, leading to non-healing or chronic ulceration.
  • Types:
    • Acute ulcers: Present with acute infection and severe acute inflammation.
    • Chronic ulcers: Long-standing ulcers without signs of acute inflammation.
    • Complicated chronic ulcers: These ulcers result from the spread of infection to deeper structures like the underlying bone, joint, or tendon sheath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restart MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy is used to treat active infections caused by Mycobacterium leprae. However, in this case, the patient has completed treatment, and the ulcer is due to neuropathy, not an active infection. Therefore, restarting MDT is not necessary and would not address the ulcer.

 

Option C. Aggressive Debridement with IV antibiotics: Aggressive debridement and IV antibiotics are typically indicated for infected ulcers or those with acute signs of inflammation. In this case, the ulcer is chronic and not primarily due to infection, so this approach is not warranted.

 

Option D. Amputation: Amputation is a last resort, reserved for cases where ulcers have led to severe, life-threatening complications such as osteomyelitis that cannot be managed by other means. This is not the case here, and such an extreme measure is not necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of chronic trophic ulcers in leprosy, reducing pressure on the ulcerated area through weight redistribution, such as with a plaster cast, is essential to promote healing and prevent further complication

choices.text: Initiate diuretic therapy with blood pressure monitoring

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath. His heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his BP is 80/60 mm Hg. An echocardiogram was done and reveals diastolic collapse of the right ventricle. X-ray was done and is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform pericardiocentesis

 

The patient's presentation, including hypotension, tachycardia, and echocardiographic findings of diastolic collapse of the right ventricle, strongly indicates cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac leads to increased intrapericardial pressure, impairing cardiac filling. The diastolic collapse of the right ventricle seen on echocardiography is a classic sign of tamponade. Immediate management involves pericardiocentesis, which involves draining the pericardial fluid to relieve pressure on the heart. Even removing a small volume of fluid can be lifesaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiate diuretic therapy with blood pressure monitoring: Diuretic therapy would worsen the patient's condition by decreasing preload, further compromising cardiac output in the setting of tamponade. This intervention would be catastrophic and should not be performed.

 

Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump insertion: An intra-aortic balloon pump is used in cardiogenic shock or mechanical complications of myocardial infarction, but it does not address the primary problem of fluid accumulation in tamponade. It is ineffective in this context.

 

Option D. Implant a ventricular assist device: Ventricular assist devices are used for refractory heart failure, especially left ventricular failure, and are not appropriate in the acute management of cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with signs of cardiac tamponade, immediate pericardiocentesis is the most appropriate and potentially life-saving intervention.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes USG examination. She is found to have twins, but one-month age gap in twins on USG scan. What is this phenomenon called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superfetation

 

Superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a second pregnancy occurs while a woman is already pregnant, resulting in twins with different ages. This happens due to two separate acts of intercourse occurring in two different menstrual cycles, leading to two embryos of different gestational ages. In superfetation, one baby is conceived during one cycle, and another baby is conceived in a subsequent cycle, often resulting in a noticeable size difference between the two babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superfecundation: Superfecundation also involves twins and separate acts of intercourse; however, it occurs within the same menstrual cycle. This means that two ova are fertilized at or near the same time, leading to twins of the same gestational age and size. Unlike superfetation, the twins are conceived during the same cycle.

 

Option C. Illegitimate child: This term refers to a child born outside of marriage and is not related to the phenomenon of having twins with different ages. It does not describe a medical condition or scenario of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Suppositious child: This term generally refers to a child that is wrongly supposed or believed to belong to a particular family. It is not relevant to the context of twins with a one-month age gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfetation is characterized by the occurrence of two separate pregnancies in different menstrual cycles, leading to twins of different gestational ages.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness and generalized fatigue. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic RBCs. Her serum iron is decreased and has increased RDW. Her MCV and MCH were also low, and TIBC was high. What would her serum transferrin saturation be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced

 

The clinical presentation and lab findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Serum iron levels are low as the body lacks sufficient iron.
  • TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity) is high as the body tries to compensate by increasing its capacity to bind iron.
  • Transferrin saturation is the percentage of transferrin (an iron-transport protein) that is saturated with iron. It is calculated as (Serum Iron / TIBC) x 100.
  • Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, the transferrin saturation will be reduced. Typically, in iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is less than 20%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased: This is incorrect.

 

Option C. Equivocal: This is incorrect.

 

Option D. Cannot be determined: This is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, transferrin saturation is reduced (typically less than 20%) due to low serum iron and high TIBC.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

choices.text: IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control.
Direct oral anticoagulants to be given.
Cardioversion should be done in hemodynamically unstable patients.
Beta blockers are given if the patient has decompensated heart failure and intolerant to calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. On examination, he has an irregularly irregular pulse with bilateral basal crackles. An ECG shows a ventricular response of 110/min. Which of the following statements is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta blockers are given if the patient has decompensated heart failure and intolerant to calcium channel blockers

 

This statement is incorrect because beta blockers are not recommended in patients with decompensated heart failure. Beta blockers are negative inotropic agents, meaning they decrease the force of the heart's contractions. In a patient with decompensated heart failure, the heart is already struggling to pump blood effectively and further reducing its contractility can worsen the condition. The first-line treatment for rate control in atrial fibrillation with decompensated heart failure is typically calcium channel blockers or digoxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control: This statement is correct. Digoxin is often used for rate control in atrial fibrillation, especially in patients with heart failure. It works by slowing the conduction of electrical signals through the atrioventricular (AV) node, thereby reducing the heart rate.

 

Option B. Direct oral anticoagulants to be given: This statement is generally correct. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for stroke prevention in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation unless there are specific contraindications such as moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve.

 

Option C. Cardioversion should be done in hemodynamically unstable patients: This statement is correct. Cardioversion, which is the process of restoring a normal heart rhythm using electrical or pharmacological means, is indicated in patients with atrial fibrillation who are hemodynamically unstable. Hemodynamic instability refers to a state where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, leading to symptoms such as low blood pressure, shortness of breath, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta blockers should be avoided in patients with decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder where phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, cannot be properly metabolized due to enzyme deficiencies. In classical PKU, the deficiency is in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, if phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are normal, as stated in the question, the problem lies elsewhere in the metabolic pathway. Dihydrobiopterin reductase is an enzyme that regenerates tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor necessary for phenylalanine hydroxylase function. If dihydrobiopterin reductase is deficient, tetrahydrobiopterin cannot be regenerated, leading to non-classical PKU despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of tyrosine, not in the initial conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine or the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin, making it unrelated to PKU.

 

Option C. Dopa decarboxylase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine from DOPA, unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D. Tyrosine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts tyrosine to DOPA and is involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of recurrent falls presented with headache and confusion. CT scan of the patient is shown. Which of the following is correct? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan of the patient shows a crescent-shaped hypodensity on the lateral side of the brain, indicative of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH). In the context of this patient, the hypodensity suggests that the bleeding is chronic. Chronic SDH typically appears darker (hypodense) on CT imaging due to the breakdown of blood products over time.

 

Chronic SDH is common in elderly patients, especially those with a history of recurrent falls or those taking antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications. This condition can occur after even trivial trauma, which elderly patients may not recall. The bleeding occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, leading to the characteristic crescent shape seen on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage occurs within the brain tissue itself and typically appears as a hyperdense (bright) area on CT in the acute phase. It does not present with the crescent shape seen in subdural hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This hemorrhage occurs in the space between the brain and the arachnoid membrane, often appearing as bright, hyperdense areas in the sulci and basal cisterns on CT. It does not have the characteristic crescent shape of a subdural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Epidural hemorrhage: Epidural hemorrhages usually present as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdensity on CT, typically associated with trauma, especially to the middle meningeal artery. It is not consistent with the crescent-shaped hypodensity seen in this patient’s scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic subdural hemorrhage presents as a crescent-shaped hypodense area on CT and is common in elderly patients with a history of falls or those on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with features as given in the image below.What is the likely  diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Arsenic

 

The image shows characteristic features of arsenic poisoning, including Mees' lines (Aldrich Mees lines) on the nails, which are transverse white lines seen in cases of heavy metal poisoning, particularly arsenic and thallium. The skin findings, such as hyperpigmentation and "raindrop" appearance, are also commonly associated with chronic arsenic exposure. Even though thallium poisoning can also present with similar nail changes, arsenic is the best answer unless alopecia is specifically noted, which is more common in thallium poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, psychological disturbances, and gingivitis, not with the distinct Mees' lines and skin changes seen here.

 

Option C. Lead: Lead poisoning commonly affects the nervous system and presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, constipation, and lead lines on the gums (Burton’s lines), not the nail and skin changes shown in the image.

 

Option D. Copper: Copper toxicity, such as Wilson's disease, typically presents with liver, neurological symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes, not with Mees' lines or the described skin pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mees' lines and raindrop pigmentation of the skin are classic signs of arsenic poisoning. In the absence of alopecia, arsenic is the preferred diagnosis over thallium.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of School Health under Ayushman Bharat Program? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Monthly IFA supplementations

 

The Ayushman Bharat Program includes a comprehensive school health component aimed at improving the health and hygiene of school children. The key components include:

 

  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS): This involves the distribution of iron and folic acid supplements on a weekly basis to prevent anemia among school children. Monthly supplementation is not part of this program; hence, "Monthly IFA supplementations" is the incorrect option.
  • Sanitary Napkins Distribution: Under the menstrual hygiene scheme, sanitary napkins branded as "Freedays" are distributed to adolescent girls to promote menstrual hygiene.
  • Albendazole for Deworming: Deworming through albendazole is conducted to reduce the prevalence of intestinal worm infestations among school-aged children.
  • Health Check-ups: Regular health screenings are conducted to assess the physical and mental fitness of students, ensuring early identification and management of health issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat School Health Program includes weekly IFA supplementation, not monthly, along with other health initiatives like menstrual hygiene, deworming, screening health check-ups, physical & mental fitness, Research and Vaccination

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

choices.text: Atrophy of the right lower limb
Loss of proprioception in the left leg
Ankle clonus in the right foot

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a RTA and was admitted to a hospital. After a few days, he had an exaggerated right-sided extensor plantar reflex and knee jerk. What other finding would be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankle clonus in the right foot

 

The presentation suggests Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is a hemisection of the spinal cord. In this condition, there's:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side) findings:
    • Loss of proprioception and fine touch due to damage to the posterior column.
    • Upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spasticity, exaggerated reflexes, ankle clonus) due to damage to the corticospinal tract.
  • Contralateral (opposite side) findings:
    • Loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of the right lower limb: Atrophy is a feature of lower motor neuron lesions, not upper motor neuron lesions seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of proprioception in the left leg: Loss of proprioception would be on the same side (right leg) as the lesion in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Option D. Fasciculations in the right foot: Fasciculations are also a sign of lower motor neuron lesions and are not expected in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsilateral loss of proprioception and upper motor neuron signs, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. A hallmark of this condition is the presence of tendon xanthomas, which are cholesterol deposits typically found in tendons, most commonly in the Achilles tendon. This condition is caused by mutations affecting the LDL receptor or apolipoprotein B, which impair the clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The Achilles tendon xanthomas are a distinctive feature that helps differentiate familial hypercholesterolemia from other lipid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is characterized by very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and the presence of orange-colored tonsils due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters. It does not cause tendon xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Familial hyperchylomicronemia: This condition involves elevated triglycerides due to the accumulation of chylomicrons, often leading to eruptive xanthomas rather than tendon xanthomas. It is primarily associated with defects in lipoprotein lipase or apolipoprotein C-II and is not associated with the specific finding of Achilles tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia: This condition, associated with a defect in apolipoprotein E, leads to increased levels of both cholesterol and triglycerides, often resulting in palmar xanthomas or tuberous xanthomas, not the specific Achilles tendon xanthomas seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of tendon xanthomas, particularly on the Achilles tendon

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

choices.text: GH levels after 2 hours of administration of 75g glucose

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with large, sweaty hands, macroglossia, and prominent frontal bossing. The patient also reports increasing shoe size and difficulty wearing rings that previously fit. Considering the clinical features, which of the following tests is the most appropriate initial investigation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Age-matched IGF-1 levels

 

The clinical features described—large hands, macroglossia, prominent frontal bossing, and changes in shoe and ring sizes—are characteristic of acromegaly, a condition caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. The initial and most appropriate screening test for acromegaly is measuring age-matched IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor-1) levels. IGF-1 reflects average GH levels and is less variable than GH, making it a reliable marker for diagnosing acromegaly. The test must be age-matched because IGF-1 levels naturally decline with age, and using incorrect age ranges could lead to misinterpretation of results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GHRH levels: Measuring GHRH is rarely useful in the initial assessment and is reserved for cases where ectopic GHRH secretion is suspected. It is not a primary diagnostic tool for acromegaly.

 

Option C. Random GH levels: Random measurement of GH is not reliable due to the pulsatile nature of GH secretion. Levels fluctuate throughout the day, making this test inappropriate for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Option D. GH levels after 2 hours of administration of 75g glucose: This is a confirmatory test, not an initial screening test. Normally, GH levels should be suppressed to undetectable levels (<1 ng/mL) following glucose administration. Failure of suppression confirms acromegaly but is not used as the first line of investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test of choice for acromegaly is measuring age-matched IGF-1 levels, which serves as a reliable screening method due to its consistent reflection of GH levels over time.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman came with complaints of weakness and lethargy with a past history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her peripheral blood smear showed microcytic RBCs. Her lab reports are as follows - Hb 7.9 mg/dl, MCV 65, MCH - low, TIBC - increased, Transferrin saturation - low. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with low mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and low mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH). The patient’s lab findings, including a low hemoglobin level (7.9 g/dL), low MCV (65), and low transferrin saturation, are classic for iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, her past history of heavy menstrual bleeding suggests chronic blood loss, which is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia.

 

The elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low transferrin saturation further confirm iron deficiency, as the body increases TIBC in an attempt to bind and transport more iron due to the deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia usually presents with normocytic red blood cells and a high reticulocyte count due to increased red blood cell turnover. It does not present with microcytic RBCs and does not have the iron deficiency profile seen here.

 

Option C. Hypoplastic anemia (Aplastic anemia): This type of anemia involves bone marrow failure, often presenting with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) and normocytic or macrocytic RBCs, not microcytic RBCs. Iron parameters are generally normal or can be elevated due to reduced erythropoiesis.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytic RBCs due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not microcytic RBCs. It does not fit the patient's lab profile of low MCV and iron deficiency markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, low hemoglobin, low MCV, increased TIBC, and low transferrin saturation, often caused by chronic blood loss such as heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The classical presentation includes leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and an intraocular mass. Histopathologically, the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a key diagnostic feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around an empty lumen, resembling a flower.

 

In this case:

 

  • Leukocoria is a typical clinical presentation of retinoblastoma.
  • The intraocular mass in a child further supports this diagnosis.
  • The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes confirms the diagnosis, as they are pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: While melanoma can occur in the eye, it is more common in adults and typically does not present with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Intraocular lymphoma is rare in children and typically presents differently, without the characteristic rosettes seen in retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignancy affects the ocular surface and is not typically associated with intraocular masses or leukocoria. It also lacks the histological pattern of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

questions.text: How much is the distance between the victim and the firearm from the gunshot entry based on the wound given below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Close Contact

 

The image provided shows a gunshot wound with visible tattooing (stippling) around the wound. Tattooing is caused by the impact of unburnt gunpowder particles striking the skin. In close contact range wounds, singeing, blackening, and tattooing are typically seen around the wound, indicating the gun was fired from a very short distance, but not directly pressed against the skin.

 

In this question, since tattooing is visible around the wound without evidence of singeing or blackening directly at the wound margins, it aligns with characteristics of a close contact shot. Ideally, if "Intermediate Range" was an option, it would fit better because it specifically involves tattooing without other signs like singeing and blackening; however, given the choices, close contact remains the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact Entry: In contact range, the muzzle of the firearm is directly against the skin, causing blackening, singeing, and tattooing only at the margins of the wound, not around it. This differs from what is seen in the image, ruling this option out.

 

Option C. Distant Range: In distant range wounds, there are no signs of singeing, blackening, or tattooing around the entry wound, as the gunpowder does not reach the skin. The presence of tattooing makes this answer incorrect.

 

Option D. Cannot be predicted: This option is incorrect because the presence of tattooing around the wound provides specific information about the distance between the firearm and the victim, allowing us to make an informed decision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing (stippling) around a gunshot wound indicates a close contact or intermediate range. The absence of singeing or blackening suggests the firearm was not in direct contact but was fired from a short distance, such as close contact.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burn Marshall

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is a technique used during breech deliveries. This maneuver involves gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen by holding the baby's ankles. The purpose is to facilitate the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation. It requires careful handling to avoid neck injury and to maintain control during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wigand: The Wigand maneuver is another technique used in obstetrics, but it is not related to breech delivery or involves swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen.

 

Option C. Mauriceau Smellie Viet: This maneuver is used during breech delivery but involves supporting the baby's body on the obstetrician's forearm with the index and middle fingers placed on the maxilla to flex the head. It does not involve swinging the baby and is distinct from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Option D. Prague: The Prague maneuver is used in breech delivery, specifically when the baby's arms are extended above the head. The obstetrician rotates the baby to facilitate arm delivery before the head, differing from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is characterized by gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: Septal perforation caused due to surgery of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SMR (Submucous Resection)

  

Septal perforation is more commonly associated with SMR (Submucous Resection) than with septoplasty. In SMR, the deviated part of the septum, which includes both the bony and cartilaginous components, is removed. This removal can lead to the loss of structural support from the cartilage or bone. If there is any tear in the mucosal flaps that cover the septum, it may fail to heal properly due to the absence of underlying support, leading to a septal perforation.

 

During SMR, the absence of this central support structure means that even a minor mucosal tear can result in a perforation because the mucosal flaps on either side of the septum may fuse incorrectly, creating a hole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): FESS is a procedure focused on the sinuses and not the septum itself, thus it does not typically result in septal perforation. This surgery involves the removal of sinus tissue and does not interfere with the septal structure.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: In septoplasty, the septum is straightened by removing or reshaping the cartilage and bone but importantly, the removed parts are replaced back between the mucosal flaps. This restoration of structure reduces the likelihood of perforations because the mucosal layers are supported by the replaced bone or cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal perforation is a recognized complication of SMR due to the complete removal of septal cartilage and bone without replacement, which can lead to mucosal tears and eventual perforation if the layers do not heal correctly.

questions.text: For Health Education, the Motivation Model has its 1st  Step as Awareness. Its 2nd  Step is Motivation. Its 3rd  Step is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Action

 

The Motivation Model for Health Education comprises three steps:

 

  1. Awareness: This step involves generating interest in the person’s mind about the health topic or problem.
  2. Motivation: This stage includes evaluation and decision-making, where the person is encouraged and motivated to consider the health information or behavior change.
  3. Action: This is the final step where the individual accepts and adopts the health idea or practice. The person moves from motivation to implementation, engaging in the recommended health behavior.

 

Other 2 Models are –

 

  • Medical Model – This involves interaction between the patient and doctor, where the patient presents their illness, and the doctor diagnoses it as a disease.
  • Social Interactive Model

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dedication: Dedication is not explicitly a step in the Motivation Model but can be an outcome of sustained action and commitment to the behavior change.

 

Option C. Contemplation: Contemplation is a stage in other health behavior change models, such as the Transtheoretical Model, where individuals consider changing but do not yet take action. It is not the third step in the Motivation Model.

 

Option D. Reflection: Reflection is not part of the Motivation Model’s steps. It typically refers to thinking back on actions and decisions, often occurring after the behavior has been implemented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third step in the Motivation Model for Health Education is Action, which signifies the adoption and implementation of the health behavior.

questions.text: Cogwheel sign on ultrasound is seen in? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrosalpinx

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a classic appearance seen in hydrosalpinx, which is a condition characterized by the dilation of the fallopian tube filled with serous fluid. This appearance occurs due to the presence of longitudinal folds within the dilated tube, giving a cogwheel-like projection visible on a cross-sectional ultrasound image. The cogwheel sign is highly suggestive of a chronic hydrosalpinx and helps differentiate it from other adnexal pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer can present with a variety of ultrasound findings, such as complex cystic structures or solid masses, but the cogwheel sign is not associated with ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Endometriosis may appear on ultrasound as ovarian endometriomas, commonly called "chocolate cysts," which have a homogenous ground-glass appearance. The cogwheel sign is not typical of endometriosis.

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, have characteristic appearances such as echogenic nodules, calcifications, and sometimes the "tip of the iceberg" sign on ultrasound. The cogwheel sign does not pertain to dermoid cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cogwheel sign on ultrasound is a key diagnostic feature of hydrosalpinx, representing the cross-sectional view of a dilated fallopian tube with internal folds.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely based on the lab values shown - Blood pH 7.28, Na 138 mEq/L, K 2.8 mEq/L, Cl 113 mEq/L, HCO3 12 mEq/L, BUN 3 mg/dL, and creatinine 0.2 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed a urinary pH of 9. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 RTA

 

The patient’s laboratory findings indicate metabolic acidosis with a blood pH of 7.28, low bicarbonate (HCO3 of 12 mEq/L), and normal anion gap, suggesting a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). The hypokalemia (K 2.8 mEq/L) and a urinary pH of 9, which indicates alkaline urine, are key diagnostic clues.

 

Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA), also known as distal RTA, is characterized by the inability of the distal nephron to acidify the urine, resulting in a persistently high urinary pH (usually >5.5). This condition often presents with hypokalemia due to impaired hydrogen ion excretion. The patient’s alkaline urine and hypokalemia strongly support the diagnosis of Type 1 RTA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 4 RTA: Type 4 RTA typically presents with hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance, which is not seen here. The presence of hypokalemia rules out this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Type 2 RTA: Type 2 RTA, or proximal RTA, involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption. While it also presents with metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia, the urine can often be acidified after a bicarbonate load, resulting in a lower pH. The high urinary pH observed here is not consistent with Type 2 RTA.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: This condition would present with elevated pCO2 and acidemia due to impaired ventilation. The patient's normal anion gap and metabolic acidosis rule out respiratory acidosis as a diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 1 RTA (distal RTA) is identified by a combination of metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and an inability to acidify the urine, leading to an alkaline urinary pH, which is a distinct feature not seen in other RTAs.

questions.text: Audiogram of a patient is given. Find the sign that can be seen in the same case. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwartz sign

 

The audiogram shows a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz, known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis. Otosclerosis is a condition where abnormal bone growth occurs in the middle ear, particularly affecting the stapes bone, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Schwartz sign is associated with otosclerosis and refers to a reddish hue seen behind the intact tympanic membrane near the oval window due to increased vascularity from active otosclerotic processes. It is a contraindication for stapes surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balance sign: This sign is unrelated to otosclerosis. Balance sign generally refers to signs related to balance issues and is not associated with hearing loss patterns on an audiogram.

 

Option B. Hennebert sign: Hennebert sign is a false positive fistula test that does not relate to otosclerosis. It is more commonly associated with conditions like Ménière's disease or syphilis affecting the inner ear.

 

Option D. Hitzelberger sign: This sign is seen in acoustic neuroma and involves hypesthesia of the posterior wall of the external auditory canal. It is not connected with otosclerosis or the Carhart's notch observed in the audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz on an audiogram is a specific finding in otosclerosis, and Schwartz sign, a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane, is an associated clinical sign indicating active otosclerotic processes.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer’s symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that commonly affects children. It is characterized by multiple patches of hair loss, which are often associated with itching and scaling.

 

The history of a sibling with similar symptoms strongly suggests an infectious cause, which aligns with the diagnosis of tinea capitis. The condition is caused by dermatophyte fungi, and the transmission occurs via direct contact or shared objects, making it contagious, particularly among children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alopecia areata: This condition leads to sudden, patchy hair loss but is not associated with itching, scaling, or being contagious. It is an autoimmune disorder rather than an infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: While this condition can cause scalp scaling, it typically does not lead to well-defined patches of hair loss or the contagious spread noted in this case.

 

Option D. Pediculosis capitis: Also known as head lice, this condition causes intense itching but does not result in patchy hair loss or scaling. The primary symptom is the presence of lice and nits (lice eggs) on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

questions.text: An elderly male presented to the clinic with fatigue, headache, backache, and renal dysfunction. He had elevated calcium levels also. His serum electrophoresis had an M spike and the immunofixation pattern has been presented alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma with elevated IgM

 

The clinical presentation of an elderly male with fatigue, headache, backache, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia is suggestive of a plasma cell disorder, such as multiple myeloma. The key diagnostic clue is the presence of an M spike on serum electrophoresis, indicating a monoclonal gammopathy. Immunofixation Electrophoresis (IFE) separates immunoglobulin heavy and light chains:

 

  • G = IgG
  • A = IgA
  • M = IgM
  • K = Kappa light chain
  • L = Lambda light chain

 

The elevated IgM and the overproduction of kappa light chains suggest a diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, commonly referred to as Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, which falls under the broader category of plasma cell cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe systemic infection: Infections usually cause polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, where multiple types of antibodies are elevated rather than a single monoclonal spike. The presence of monoclonality rules out this option.

 

Option B. MGUS (Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance): MGUS can present with a monoclonal spike, but it does not typically cause systemic symptoms or organ dysfunction such as renal impairment. The patient’s symptoms suggest a more severe plasma cell disorder.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG: Multiple myeloma with elevated IgG is the most common type of immunoglobulin elevated in multiple myeloma, the immunofixation pattern indicates IgM, not IgG, ruling out this choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An M spike on serum electrophoresis along with specific symptoms and immunofixation identifying elevated IgM indicates a diagnosis of multiple myeloma or a related plasma cell cancer, such as lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström's macroglobulinemia).

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening.
