Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sniffing position for intubation

 

The image illustrates the "sniffing position," which is the ideal position for tracheal intubation. In this position, the patient’s head is elevated and extended at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. This alignment facilitates a direct line of sight during laryngoscopy, making intubation easier. The sniffing position is a standard recommendation for intubating patients under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideal position for Bougie insertion: The sniffing position is primarily recognized for its role in enhancing the view during direct laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Ideal position for Neurosurgery: This option is incorrect because the sniffing position is not typically used for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery often requires specific head and neck positioning to optimize access to the brain or spine, which differs from the sniffing position.

 

Option D. Neck position for intubation: The term "neck position for intubation" is too vague. The correct terminology for the position depicted in the image is the "sniffing position," which specifically describes the head and neck alignment optimal for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with visual disturbances. An MRI reveals a lesion at the location marked in the image. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely associated with this lesion? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

The lesion refers to a craniopharyngioma, a tumor that arises from the remnants of Rathke's pouch, located near the pituitary gland.

 

Craniopharyngiomas are commonly found near the optic chiasm, where the crossing of the nasal fibers of the optic nerves occurs. When this tumor grows, it can compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia. This condition results in the loss of peripheral vision in both eyes because the tumor specifically damages the nasal fibers, which are responsible for peripheral vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single vision field loss: Single vision field loss would occur with damage to the optic nerve on one side, not at the optic chiasm. Craniopharyngiomas typically affect both nasal fibers at the chiasm, leading to a specific pattern of vision loss, not confined to a single visual field.

 

Option C. Complete blindness: Complete blindness would require extensive damage to the entire visual pathway, which is not typical of craniopharyngioma unless the tumor has become exceptionally large and invasive. The usual presentation is partial vision loss, particularly affecting the peripheral fields.

 

Option D. Homonymous hemianopia: Homonymous hemianopia occurs when there is damage to the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex on one side, leading to loss of the same visual field in both eyes. This pattern does not fit with craniopharyngioma, which specifically affects the optic chiasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngiomas commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, resulting in peripheral vision loss on both sides.

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Identify the following organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

     
The patient presents with symptoms of urethral discharge and dysuria, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, which strongly suggests a sexually transmitted infection. The image provided shows Gram-negative diplococci, which are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes symptoms like purulent discharge from the urethra, dysuria, and may be accompanied by other complications if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H. ducreyi: This bacterium causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia, not typically associated with pus discharge and dysuria as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Candida: While Candida species can cause infections, they usually lead to candidiasis, presenting with symptoms like itching, discharge, and irritation but not the Gram-negative diplococci seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:


Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, characterized by urethral discharge and dysuria, especially following unprotected sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have bilateral tubal block on HSG. The next best step is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy with chromotubation

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is often the first test used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes in women experiencing infertility. If the HSG reveals a bilateral tubal block, the next best step is to confirm the findings through laparoscopy with chromotubation. This procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the fallopian tubes. Chromotubation involves the injection of a dye through the fallopian tubes to assess their patency directly, which is more accurate than imaging alone. Additionally, if the block is confirmed, there may be an opportunity to address it surgically during the same procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVF: While IVF is a valid treatment option for tubal factor infertility, it is generally considered after confirming the tubal block with laparoscopy. IVF is often chosen if re-canalization attempts fail or if the patient prefers to bypass surgery.

 

Option C. IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): IUI is not suitable in cases of confirmed bilateral tubal block because it requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm to reach the egg.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Letrozole is an ovulation induction agent used in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It is not appropriate for treating tubal block issues and thus is not relevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After identifying a bilateral tubal block on HSG in a woman with primary infertility, the next best step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromotubation before considering other treatments like IVF.

questions.text: Identify the organ most likely lined by the type of epithelium seen in the provided histological section. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ureter

 

The histology slide shown displays transitional epithelium, also known as urothelium. Transitional epithelium is characterized by multiple layers of cells with a distinct upper layer composed of umbrella cells, which are often binucleated and exhibit a dome-shaped appearance. These umbrella cells allow the epithelium to stretch and accommodate varying volumes of fluid, a feature that is crucial for organs in the urinary system like the ureter, bladder, and renal pelvis. This epithelium type is specific to the urinary tract, allowing it to expand and contract without losing integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: The duodenum is lined with simple columnar epithelium with microvilli, designed for absorption and not seen in multilayered transitional cells.

 

Option B. Gall bladder: The gall bladder has a simple columnar epithelium without cilia or transitional characteristics. Its primary function is to concentrate and store bile, requiring an absorptive surface rather than a stretchable one.

 

Option C. Trachea: The trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium containing goblet cells, designed to trap and move particles, which is distinct from the structure of transitional epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transitional epithelium, marked by umbrella cells and multilayered structure, is primarily found in the urinary tract, including the ureter,  urinary bladder and upper part of urethra where it facilitates expansion and contraction.

choices.text: It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis
The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test
Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition
The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following is a true/correct statement about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition


Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an acquired, not inherited, clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder that leads to red blood cell destruction (intravascular hemolysis), thrombosis, and bone marrow failure.

 

The gold standard for diagnosing PNH is flow cytometry, which detects the absence of GPI-anchored proteins (CD55 and CD59) on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.

 

 The absence of these proteins makes cells vulnerable to complement-mediated destruction, characteristic of PNH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis: This statement is incorrect because PNH is not inherited but acquired due to a somatic mutation in the PIGA gene in hematopoietic stem cells.

 

Option B. The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test: The sucrose lysis test is an older screening test for PNH but is not confirmatory. It has largely been replaced by flow cytometry, which is more accurate and specific for detecting the absence of CD55 and CD59.

 

Option D. The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure: This statement is incorrect. The most common cause of mortality in PNH is thrombotic complications, especially hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd-Chiari syndrome), not cardiac failure.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the definitive test for diagnosing PNH by demonstrating the absence of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells.

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid used to treat diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. However, like other opioids, it carries a risk of abuse, especially if taken in large doses. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is mixed with diphenoxylate in subtherapeutic doses to deter misuse. When taken as prescribed, the amount of atropine is too small to cause significant effects. However, if someone tries to abuse diphenoxylate by taking a large number of tablets, the atropine will also accumulate and cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision. These side effects are uncomfortable and discourage further abuse of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is incorrect because atropine is not added to decrease the adverse effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, when taken in large doses, atropine can add to the side effects rather than diminish them.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: While atropine also has anticholinergic properties that can reduce gastrointestinal motility, it is not added for this purpose in the combination. The primary reason for its inclusion is to prevent abuse, not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Although atropine can reduce spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, it is not included in this combination for its spasmolytic action. The dose of atropine used is subtherapeutic and does not significantly contribute to spasmolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

choices.text: B scan of both the eyes

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with GTCS (Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures) and was admitted. CECT is shown below. Which of the following can be useful in establishing the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NMR spectroscopy

 

The CECT scan shows a single ring-enhancing lesion near the parieto-occipital region, which raises differential diagnoses, including brain abscess, primary CNS lymphoma, tuberculoma, and neurocysticercosis. Among these, the most relevant differential in this patient is tuberculoma versus neurocysticercosis. NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance) spectroscopy is useful in distinguishing between these conditions. In tuberculoma, NMR spectroscopy typically shows a characteristic lipid and/or lactate peak, while in neurocysticercosis, it shows multiple amino acid peaks. This makes NMR spectroscopy the most appropriate tool for establishing the diagnosis in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is primarily used to confirm TB meningitis, which is not the primary suspicion in this patient. The clinical presentation does not fit TB meningitis, and the test is unlikely to be positive in cases of tuberculoma.

 

Option B. PET scan: A PET scan is typically useful for assessing metabolic activity in tumors but is not the best initial choice for differentiating tuberculoma from neurocysticercosis.

 

Option D. B scan of both the eyes: A B scan, or ultrasound of the eyes, is used if intraocular neurocysticercosis is suspected. However, there is no indication of ocular involvement in this patient, making it less relevant for this particular diagnostic dilemma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NMR spectroscopy is valuable in distinguishing between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis, especially when a single ring-enhancing lesion is present on imaging.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of a child undergoing inguinal hernia repair is shown, with a marked vein in the spermatic cord. What is the likely structure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular vein

 

During an open inguinal hernia repair, especially in the context of congenital hernias, the structures encountered within the spermatic cord are crucial for identification and preservation. The testicular vein is one of the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord, alongside the testicular artery and vas deferens. This vein is responsible for draining blood from the testes and is often seen during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

In the provided intraoperative image, the marked structure is consistent with the testicular vein due to its anatomical position and its association with the spermatic cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vein: The femoral vein lies posterior to the inguinal canal and is not encountered during an open inguinal hernia repair. It is located within the femoral triangle and is not related to the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Obturator vein: The obturator vein is also located posterior to the inguinal canal, passing through the obturator foramen. It is not visible or involved in inguinal hernia repairs as it lies deep in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Inferior epigastric vein: The inferior epigastric vein is positioned anterior to the peritoneum and supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It does not travel within the spermatic cord and would not be seen during an open hernia repair involving the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an open inguinal hernia repair, the primary veins associated with the spermatic cord are the testicular veins. Other veins such as the femoral, obturator, and inferior epigastric veins are located posterior to the inguinal canal and are not seen within the spermatic cord during such procedures.

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

questions.text: Which of the following growth hormone analogue that is not used for treatment of GH deficiency but is used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tesamorelin

 

Tesamorelin is a synthetic analogue of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) that is specifically used in the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, a condition characterized by abnormal distribution of body fat in patients with HIV. Tesamorelin reduces visceral adipose tissue and improves the body composition of individuals with this condition. Unlike other growth hormone analogues, Tesamorelin is not primarily used for treating growth hormone deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sermorelin: Sermorelin is a synthetic analogue of GHRH used to diagnose and treat growth hormone deficiency. It is not indicated for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option C. Somatropin: Somatropin is a recombinant form of human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies. It is not used for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It is not used for HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing hormone analogue used specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, distinguishing it from other growth hormone analogues that are used for treating growth hormone deficiencies.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

questions.text: A child had a fall at home and was treated with an elbow cast. After the removal of the cast, the child developed the deformity as shown. Which fracture most likely caused this deformity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

The image shows a child with a deformity known as cubitus varus, which is a complication of supracondylar humerus fractures. This deformity occurs when the distal part of the arm deviates medially, leading to a "gunstock" appearance of the arm. Cubitus varus is a known consequence of a malunited supracondylar humerus fracture, where the carrying angle of the elbow is reduced.

 

Supracondylar fractures are common in children, especially after a fall on an outstretched hand, and improper alignment during healing can lead to this deformity. The deformity is mostly a cosmetic issue but is directly associated with this type of fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial head fracture: Radial head fractures typically present with pain during rotation of the forearm and do not commonly cause cubitus varus or valgus deformities. The main issue with radial head fractures is decreased range of motion, particularly pronation and supination, rather than a visible deformity like in this case.

 

Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture: A lateral condyle fracture can lead to cubitus valgus, where the distal part of the arm deviates laterally, increasing the carrying angle. This is the opposite deformity to cubitus varus, which we see here. Non-union of lateral condyle fractures is the common cause of cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus.

 

Option C. Mid-shaft humerus fracture: A mid-shaft humerus fracture does not typically result in deformities like cubitus varus. While this fracture can result in functional issues, especially related to nerve injury (such as radial nerve palsy), it does not lead to elbow deformities unless complicated by additional elbow injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus varus, a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.

questions.text: In a community, there were 550 births in a year out of which 50 were stillbirths. There were 09 deaths among newborns during 0-7 days of life. An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 18

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) measures the number of deaths of newborns within the first 7 days of life per 1,000 live births. It focuses specifically on early neonatal deaths, which occur during the first week of life.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 550
  • Stillbirths: 50
  • Live births (LB): 550 - 50 = 500
  • Early Neonatal Deaths (ENND): 9 deaths during 0-7 days.

 

ENMR formula:

 

 

Therefore, the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is 18 deaths per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.

questions.text: Diagnose the X-ray as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteosarcoma


Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that typically shows characteristic radiographic features such as the "sunburst" or "sun ray" appearance, which is caused by the tumor's aggressive growth pattern. In addition to this, Codman’s triangle may be visible, which occurs when the tumor lifts the periosteum off the bone, forming a triangular area of new bone formation. The lower end of the femur is a common site for osteosarcoma, as well as other long bones in the body.

 

In the provided X-rays, the sun ray appearance is clearly visible, making osteosarcoma the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroblastoma: This tumor typically presents with calcifications in the epiphyseal (end) regions of bones, particularly in the upper end of the humerus. However, chondroblastoma does not present with a sun ray appearance.

 

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: This is another malignant tumor, but it primarily affects the upper end of the femur or pelvis. The X-ray for chondrosarcoma typically shows dense calcifications, but not the sun ray pattern associated with osteosarcoma.

 

 

Option C. Ewing's sarcoma: This tumor often presents with a diaphyseal (shaft) lesion in long bones and can cause an "onion-skin" appearance due to the layered periosteal reaction. It does not exhibit the sun ray pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The sun ray appearance and Codman’s triangle in X-rays are key indicators of osteosarcoma, especially in the lower end of long bones like the femur.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness in performing daily activities. On examination, the clinician asked her to make an 'O' using her thumb and index finger, which she was unable to do. Which of the following muscles is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to form an 'O' using the thumb and index finger suggests a problem with muscles that control flexion of these digits, specifically the flexor pollicis longus, which is responsible for flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx. This muscle is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. The condition described in the question is consistent with anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, which impairs the flexion of the distal phalanges of the thumb and index finger, making it difficult to perform tasks requiring precise pinch or grip, such as buttoning a shirt.

 

In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus are affected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmar interossei: These muscles are primarily involved in the adduction of the fingers (PAD - Palmar Adducts), and they do not play a role in flexing the thumb or index finger. Therefore, they are not related to the inability to form an 'O'.

 

Option B. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in the opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the other fingers. It is not directly responsible for flexion of the thumb or index finger and is innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve. Its dysfunction would affect opposition rather than the ability to form an 'O'.

 

Note an update - Opponens pollicis, a hybrid muscle, as innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve, and commonly by a branch of the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is responsible for the abduction of the thumb, moving it away from the palm. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx, which is necessary to form an 'O'. Thus, its involvement does not explain the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome affects the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles, leading to difficulty in forming an 'O' with the thumb and index finger due to impaired flexion.

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

questions.text: A patient had enlarging nodules present on his scalp. He was taking prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. His clinical lesion and the histopathological lesion are shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malakoplakia

 

The patient's clinical history and biopsy findings suggest a diagnosis of Malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition that is often associated with immunosuppressive states, such as in patients taking medications like prednisolone, mycophenolate, and tacrolimus.

 

The characteristic histopathological feature of Malakoplakia is the presence of Michaelis-Guttmann bodies, which are basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions with a "targetoid" appearance seen in macrophages.

 

These bodies result from incomplete phagocytosis and subsequent calcium and iron deposition.

 

Malakoplakia commonly affects the urinary bladder but can also present in other organs, including the skin, as seen in this patient with scalp lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis would typically present with caseating granulomas, which are not seen in the provided histopathological image. The characteristic Michaelis-Guttmann bodies in this image rule out tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Pyoderma gangrenosum: This condition is usually associated with painful ulcerative skin lesions and does not present with the histopathological findings seen here. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not associated with Michaelis-Guttmann bodies.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lesion: Drug-induced skin lesions generally present with nonspecific inflammation or necrosis rather than granulomatous inflammation with the distinct Michaelis-Guttmann bodies characteristic of Malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous condition marked by Michaelis-Guttmann bodies and is often seen in immunosuppressed patients. It can affect organs beyond the urinary bladder, including the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of death in patients with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory Failure

 

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung tissue, which leads to a decline in lung function over time. The most common cause of death in patients with IPF is respiratory failure. This occurs due to the severe impairment of gas exchange caused by extensive fibrosis, which leads to hypoxia and the inability of the lungs to adequately oxygenate the blood. As the disease progresses, the fibrosis worsens, ultimately resulting in fatal respiratory failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Artery Hypertension: Pulmonary hypertension can occur as a complication of IPF due to chronic hypoxemia, but it is not the leading cause of death. It often exacerbates the overall decline but does not directly cause mortality as frequently as respiratory failure.

 

Option C. Aspiration Pneumonia: While aspiration pneumonia can occur in patients with IPF, particularly due to impaired cough reflexes or swallowing difficulties, it is not the primary cause of death in these patients.

 

Option D. Lung Cancer: Lung cancer is a recognized comorbidity in patients with IPF and does contribute to mortality. However, it is not the most common cause of death compared to respiratory failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death in patients with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis due to the progressive decline in lung function caused by extensive fibrosis.

choices.text: Free iron is toxic for the cells
Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin
Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood
Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Free iron is toxic for the cells

 

Free iron in the body is highly reactive and can catalyze the formation of free radicals, leading to oxidative stress and cellular damage. This is why iron is typically bound to proteins such as transferrin in the blood and ferritin within cells to prevent free iron from causing harm. The body has mechanisms to tightly regulate iron levels to avoid toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron will be stored in the form of transferrin: This statement is incorrect. Transferrin is a transport protein that carries iron in the bloodstream. Iron is stored in the body as ferritin or hemosiderin, not transferrin.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via Apoferritin in the blood: This is incorrect. Apoferritin binds iron to form ferritin, which is used for storage, not transport. Iron transport in the blood is mainly handled by transferrin.

 

Option D. Hepcidin enhances iron transport through Ferroportin: This is incorrect. Hepcidin actually inhibits iron transport by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation. This reduces the amount of iron released into the bloodstream from cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free iron is toxic to cells due to its ability to generate reactive oxygen species, which can cause significant cellular damage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with headache, palpitations, and hypertension. On evaluation, his urinary VMA and catecholamines were elevated. Imaging revealed an adrenal mass, and the patient underwent surgery and resection. Histology of the mass was shown. Which of the following is true regarding the condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Can be seen in MEN 2A

 

The patient’s symptoms, elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamines, and the presence of an adrenal mass indicate pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor. Pheochromocytomas can present with classic symptoms of headache, palpitations, and hypertension.

 

Association with MEN 2A: Pheochromocytomas are often seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A) and type 2B (MEN2B) syndromes. These syndromes are genetic conditions characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and other endocrine abnormalities. MEN2A specifically involves pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are not mostly seen in children; they occur predominantly in adults. Only about 10% of cases are seen in children.

 

Option B. Mostly malignant: Most pheochromocytomas are benign. Only about 10-15% of these tumors are malignant, contrary to the statement that they are "mostly malignant."

 

Option D. Mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are usually unilateral, with only about 10-12% being bilateral. Bilateral cases are more commonly associated with genetic conditions like MEN syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytomas can be seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes, which are genetic conditions associated with multiple endocrine tumors, including pheochromocytoma

questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. The best culture media for the following organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thayer Martin agar

 

The patient’s symptoms of urethral discharge, dysuria, and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse suggest an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a fastidious bacterium requiring enriched media for growth. Thayer Martin agar is a selective medium specifically designed to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It contains nutrients that support the growth of Neisseria species and antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to inhibit the growth of contaminating organisms, making it the best medium for culturing this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood agar: Although blood agar is a general-purpose nutrient medium that can support the growth of a wide range of bacteria, it is not selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and does not contain the necessary inhibitors to prevent the growth of other organisms.

 

Option B. MacConkey agar: This agar is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria and is typically used for isolating lactose-fermenting bacteria like Escherichia coli. It is not suitable for the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which does not thrive on this medium.

 

Option D. Wilson Blair agar: This medium is used for isolating Salmonella typhi and is not relevant to Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as it does not provide the specific growth conditions required for this organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thayer Martin agar is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a bacterium associated with sexually transmitted infections presenting as urethral discharge and dysuria.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Penectomy with inguinal dissection

 

The correct answer is Penectomy with inguinal dissection. The provided images show a post-operative scenario where the penis has been surgically removed, and a perineal urethrostomy has been created with a catheter in place. Additionally, drains are visible in the upper groin area, which are indicative of bilateral inguinal lymph node dissection. This combination of procedures is typical in the management of penile cancer, where both the primary tumor and regional lymph nodes are addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Orchidectomy: Orchidectomy, or surgical removal of one or both testicles, is not typically part of the treatment for penile cancer unless testicular involvement is specifically noted, which is not suggested by the images. The presence of inguinal dissection further confirms that this is not just an orchidectomy.

 

Option C. Debridement: Debridement is a procedure involving the removal of necrotic or infected tissue to promote wound healing. The images do not show the characteristics of a debridement procedure, such as wound cleansing or preparation for further wound care. Instead, the structured surgical approach seen suggests a more extensive oncologic procedure.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: This is combined procedure is not commonly done, and doesn’t depict the images provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penectomy with inguinal dissection is a treatment approach for penile cancer, involving removal of the penis and associated lymph node dissection to manage local and regional disease spread.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with fever and myalgia. On examination, he had a diffuse maculopapular rash. Labs revealed a Hb of 14 g/dL, Hematocrit of 55%, Total WBC count of 4000, and platelet count of 25,000. Which of the following is the best prognostic indicator? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hematocrit

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of dengue fever, a common viral infection characterized by fever, rash, myalgia, thrombocytopenia (low platelets), and elevated hematocrit due to plasma leakage.

 

Hematocrit is the best prognostic indicator in dengue fever as it reflects the severity of plasma leakage, which can lead to hypovolemia, shock, and severe dengue. Monitoring hematocrit helps guide fluid management. A rising hematocrit indicates worsening plasma leakage, necessitating aggressive fluid replacement, while a falling hematocrit in a patient with shock suggests the need for blood transfusion. This makes hematocrit a critical marker in the management of dengue, as it directly influences therapeutic decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelets: While thrombocytopenia is a common finding in dengue and is monitored closely, platelet count alone does not directly guide fluid management or predict disease severity as effectively as hematocrit.

 

Option C. Total Leukocyte Count: Leukopenia (low white blood cell count) is often seen in dengue but does not have significant prognostic value. It is not used to guide treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Albumin: Low albumin levels can occur in severe dengue due to plasma leakage, but albumin is not the primary marker used for monitoring disease progression or guiding treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue fever, hematocrit is the best prognostic indicator as it reflects the extent of plasma leakage and guides fluid management, which is crucial in preventing complications.

choices.text: Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmus because of narrowest area

 

The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the tube, which makes it an ideal site for ligation. One key reason for selecting this site is that it preserves the broader segments of the tube, such as the ampulla, which are essential if recanalization (reversal of the ligation) is needed later. By ligating the narrowest part, the wider and more functionally significant areas remain intact, facilitating easier and more successful surgical reanastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: This is incorrect because the reason for ligating at the isthmus is primarily its narrowness, not muscle structure.

 

Option C. Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: The ampulla is not the preferred site for ligation because it is wider and more functionally significant. Ligation here would complicate future recanalization procedures.

 

Option D. Ampulla because of narrowest area: This is incorrect because the ampulla is not the narrowest part of the fallopian tube; the isthmus is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the most common site for tubal ligation due to its narrowness, which preserves the broader, more functional parts of the tube, making recanalization easier if needed in the future.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of prick injury came with the complaint: swelling of the foot with sinus tracts showing pus discharge, which showed white granules and gram-positive filamentous structures were noted on microscopy. What is the most likely causative organism associated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nocardia brasiliensis

 

This clinical scenario involving a farmer, a common occupation associated with exposure to organisms causing subcutaneous infections. The key clues here are:

 

  1. Prick injury: Suggests a subcutaneous mycosis or actinomycetoma.
  2. Swelling of the foot with sinus tracts, pus discharge, and white granules: These are characteristic features of mycetoma, also known as Madura foot.
  3. Gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy: This is a hallmark of actinomycetoma, specifically caused by bacterial agents like Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Mycetoma is classified into two types based on the causative organism: Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma

 

 

Given the presence of gram-positive filamentous structures and white granules, the most likely causative organism is Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Incorrect because it causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis, but does not produce granules or gram-positive filamentous structures.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect because, although it is gram-positive and can cause abscesses and sinus tracts, it does not form filamentous structures and is not typically associated with granules as seen in mycetoma.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because it is a fungus that can cause invasive infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but does not match the presentation described (i.e., white granules and gram-positive filaments).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma, or Madura foot, caused by Nocardia brasiliensis, presents with swelling, sinus tracts, white granules, and gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy, distinguishing it from eumycetoma and other subcutaneous infections.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed suction drain

 

The drain shown in the image is a Romovac drain, which is a type of closed suction drain. Closed suction drains are used to remove fluids from a surgical site while maintaining a closed system, preventing contamination and infection. These drains have a bulb or collection reservoir that creates a negative pressure vacuum when compressed, allowing for continuous drainage of fluids from the wound site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open drain: These drains, like Penrose drains, are open systems where fluids drain passively onto a dressing or into a container, which increases the risk of infection due to exposure to the external environment.

 

Option B. Semi-open drain: These drains are a hybrid between open and closed systems, but are not as commonly used as purely open or closed systems.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: This is a type of open drain that allows passive drainage of fluids into the surrounding dressings. It is not connected to any suction mechanism or collection container.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Romovac drain is a closed suction drain that uses a vacuum system to actively remove fluids from a surgical site, reducing the risk of infection and aiding in the healing process.

choices.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release
Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal
Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

 

Explanation:

 

At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening. 

 

Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.

 

Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:
This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:

 

Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

choices.text: Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

questions.text: Patient presents with acute urinary retention, and suprapubic catheterization is done. Urethrogram show a long segment stricture. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

 

For long urethral strictures, typically those greater than 1-2 cm in length, the preferred management is urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft. This surgical approach involves using a graft from the buccal mucosa (inner cheek lining) to replace or augment the narrowed segment of the urethra, thereby restoring normal urine flow. Buccal mucosal grafts are favored due to their durability, excellent tissue characteristics, and high success rates in reconstructive urology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metal catheter: Using a metal catheter is an outdated approach and is not recommended for managing long urethral strictures due to its potential to cause trauma and worsening of the stricture.

 

Option B. Dilation: Dilation is a temporary and often less effective method for managing urethral strictures, especially long ones. It involves stretching the stricture but does not offer a long-term solution and has a high recurrence rate.

 

Option C. Endoscopic urethrotomy: Endoscopic urethrotomy, also known as visual internal urethrotomy, is typically reserved for short segment strictures (less than 1 cm). It involves using a scope to cut the stricture internally. It is not suitable for long segment strictures as it has a higher recurrence rate and limited success in longer strictures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long urethral strictures require reconstructive surgery with techniques such as urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft to provide a durable and effective solution for restoring normal urethral function.

choices.text: NHL - advanced stage - treated with radiotherapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of fever, night sweats, generalized itching, and unintentional weight loss of 10% in the last 3 months. On examination, she has enlarged cervical and axillary lymph nodes. The lymph node examination and biopsy showed the following picture. What would the likely diagnosis and treatment option be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hodgkin's Lymphoma - ABVD regimen

 

The clinical presentation of fever, night sweats, unintentional weight loss (collectively known as B symptoms), along with generalized itching and lymphadenopathy, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL). The biopsy finding of classic Reed-Sternberg cells, which are large abnormal lymphocytes often found in Hodgkin's Lymphoma, confirms this diagnosis.

 

Hodgkin’s Lymphoma is treated primarily with the ABVD regimen, which includes the drugs Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Bleomycin, Vinblastine, and Dacarbazine. This regimen is the standard initial treatment for classical Hodgkin’s Lymphoma and may be supplemented with involved site radiotherapy (ISRT) in select cases. In cases of refractory or relapsed disease, Brentuximab Vedotin, an anti-CD30 monoclonal antibody-drug conjugate, may be added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NHL - Rituximab monotherapy: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Option C. NHL - advanced stage - treated with radiotherapy: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis - Started on Prednisolone 40 mg/day: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin’s Lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy and is treated with the ABVD chemotherapy regimen, often combined with radiotherapy in specific cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly with bone marrow having 22% plasma cells. The bone marrow biopsy had a pink acellular deposition of material as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amyloidosis

 

The patient’s clinical presentation, including hepatosplenomegaly and an increased number of plasma cells (22%) in the bone marrow, suggests a plasma cell dyscrasia, most likely multiple myeloma.

 

 In multiple myeloma, there is overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, particularly lambda light chains, which can be deposited as amyloid fibrils.

 

The bone marrow biopsy showing pink acellular material confirms amyloidosis, a condition where these abnormal proteins are deposited in various tissues, including the liver and spleen, leading to organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow necrosis: This condition involves the death of bone marrow cells and would not present with acellular pink deposits seen in amyloidosis. It typically occurs due to severe conditions like leukemia or metastatic cancer.

 

Option B. T.B.: Tuberculosis affecting the bone marrow would present with granulomatous inflammation, not with a high percentage of plasma cells or acellular amyloid deposits.

 

Option C. Myxoid degeneration: This refers to a degenerative change within connective tissue, characterized by a gelatinous appearance. It does not cause acellular pink deposits and is not associated with increased plasma cells or amyloid formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloidosis can occur as a result of multiple myeloma due to the deposition of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, which can be identified as acellular pink deposits on histology.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

 

In the process of skin graft healing, the nutrition of the graft changes over time:

 

  1. Imbibition (Days 1-2): During the first two days after the graft is placed, it receives nutrition through plasmatic imbibition. This process involves the absorption of nutrients from the wound bed by diffusion into the graft.
  2. Inosculation (Days 3-5): By the third day, inosculation occurs, which involves the connection of blood vessels from the recipient bed to the blood vessels within the graft. This is a crucial step where initial vascular connections start to form between the graft and the recipient site, providing direct blood flow to the graft.
  3. Neovascularisation (After Day 5): After the fifth day, new blood vessels begin to grow into the graft from the recipient bed, a process known as neovascularization. This ensures that the graft has a stable blood supply, enhancing its long-term survival.
  4. Vascular Anastomosis: This term refers to the surgical connection of blood vessels, which is not typically a mechanism involved in the natural healing of skin grafts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imbibition: This occurs primarily in the first two days post-grafting, where the graft absorbs nutrients by diffusion but not through vascular connections.

 

Option C. Neovascularisation: This process begins after the fifth day, contributing to the long-term survival of the graft through the growth of new blood vessels.

 

Option D. Vascular anastomosis: This is not a natural stage of graft healing but refers to the surgical joining of vessels, which is unrelated to the described natural healing stages of grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

questions.text: Which segment of the vertebrae is involved in a patient presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and the leg after lifting heavy weight? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S1


The S1 nerve root is commonly involved when a patient presents with pain radiating to the back of the thigh and the leg, especially after activities such as lifting heavy weights. S1 supplies the lateral part of the sole, the small toe, and the lateral aspect of the foot, which aligns with the typical presentation of pain distribution in such cases. The S1 dermatome covers the area from the back of the thigh down to the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S2: While S2 is also located in the lower limb region, it primarily affects the posterior aspect of the thigh and the gluteal region rather than extending into the leg and foot. The symptoms described in the question align more closely with S1 involvement.

 

Option C. L5: The L5 nerve root affects the lateral thigh, anterior shin, and top of the foot, including the big toe. Pain in this dermatome does not typically extend to the back of the thigh and leg as described.

 

Option D. L4: The L4 nerve root typically affects the anterior thigh and the medial aspect of the shin. It does not extend to the back of the thigh or the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:


The S1 nerve root is involved in pain radiating to the back of the thigh and leg, especially affecting the lateral part of the foot and the small toe, common in cases of heavy lifting or nerve compression.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman presents with cervical elongation. Her family is complete. What is the preferred surgery advised? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fothergill


The Fothergill procedure, also known as the Manchester repair, is the preferred surgical treatment for women with cervical elongation who have completed their families and do not wish to have more children. This procedure involves cervical amputation and reinforcement of the pelvic ligaments, providing adequate support without removing the uterus. It is suitable for younger women who are not candidates for a hysterectomy but have significant cervical elongation contributing to prolapse symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. McCall Culdoplasty: This procedure is typically performed to correct vaginal vault prolapse during or after hysterectomy and is not specifically indicated for cervical elongation.

 

Option C. Le fort: This procedure involves partial closure of the vagina and is generally recommended for elderly, non-sexually active women who are not candidates for more invasive surgeries.

 

Option D. Shirodkar sling: This procedure is used for pelvic organ prolapse in young, nulliparous women or women who wish to preserve fertility by anchoring the uterus, usually to the sacral promontory. It is not indicated for women with completed families and cervical elongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolapse management by age group:

questions.text: An adult patient presents with tall stature, pigeon chest deformity, long arm span, lens dislocation, and cardiac defects. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibrillin

 

The clinical presentation described is strongly suggests Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue.

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. Features of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, long arms, pigeon chest (pectus carinatum), lens dislocation (typically upward and temporal), and cardiac defects such as aortic aneurysm and mitral valve prolapse. The defect in fibrillin leads to the characteristic physical and systemic manifestations of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elastase: Elastase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of elastin and is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, leading to conditions like emphysema. It is not related to Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen: Collagen defects are associated with other connective tissue disorders, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Alport syndrome. Collagen abnormalities do not explain the specific features of Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Laminin: Laminin is a major glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix, playing a key role in cell adhesion and structural integrity of tissues. It is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome is characterized by a defect in fibrillin-1 due to mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to tall stature, skeletal deformities, lens dislocation, and cardiovascular abnormalities.

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TMP

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This enzyme is critical in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, a precursor needed for the de novo synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to a decrease in thymine monophosphate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis and repair. This inhibition ultimately impedes the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, making methotrexate effective in the treatment of breast cancer and other malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate is not directly affected by methotrexate. Methotrexate does not inhibit the synthesis of purine nucleotides like AMP.

 

Option B. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide, but its synthesis is not directly impacted by methotrexate.

 

Option C. UMP: Uridine monophosphate is another pyrimidine nucleotide that is not directly influenced by methotrexate's mechanism of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a reduction in thymine monophosphate (TMP) synthesis, which is critical for DNA synthesis. This makes it effective in the treatment of cancers, including breast cancer

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: In a patient with Horner syndrome, ptosis is most likely due to paralysis of which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior tarsal muscle

 

The superior tarsal muscle, also known as Muller's muscle, is a smooth muscle that assists in elevating the upper eyelid. In Horner syndrome, there is damage to the sympathetic nerve supply, specifically the T1 nerve, which innervates the superior tarsal muscle. Paralysis of this muscle leads to ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, because the muscle cannot perform its function of aiding eyelid elevation. Horner syndrome typically results from a disruption in the sympathetic nerves, leading to symptoms like ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbitalis: This muscle provides support to the eyeball from the back. In Horner syndrome, although the orbitalis muscle may be affected, leading to a sunken appearance of the eyeball (apparent enophthalmos), it does not contribute directly to ptosis.

 

Option B. Levator superioris palpebrae: This muscle is primarily responsible for the elevation of the eyelid. However, it is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not by the sympathetic nervous system, and its paralysis leads to significant ptosis, but this condition is unrelated to Horner syndrome.

 

Option C. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Paralysis of this muscle leads to inability to close the eyelid but is not involved in ptosis due to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner syndrome is characterized by ptosis due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller's muscle), which is innervated by sympathetic fibers, particularly from the T1 spinal nerve

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: A young woman presents with prolapse. A sacrohysteropexy is being done. A mesh is being placed. Where is this mesh fixed to? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sacral promontory

 

In cases of pelvic organ prolapse, surgical procedures like sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy are performed to provide support to the prolapsed organs using a mesh.

 

  • In sacrocolpopexy, the mesh is typically fixed from the vaginal vault (in patients who have undergone a hysterectomy) to the sacral promontory.
  • In sacrohysteropexy, the mesh is fixed from the cervix to the sacral promontory, providing support to the uterus in younger patients who still have their uterus intact.

 

The sacral promontory, which is the uppermost part of the sacrum, serves as a strong and reliable point for attachment, providing the necessary support to the pelvic structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischial spine: The ischial spine is a point of attachment for pelvic muscles and ligaments, but it is not used for mesh fixation in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy.

 

Option B. Ischial tuberosity: This structure serves as an attachment site for muscles and ligaments of the pelvis, but it is not involved in sacrocolpopexy procedures.

 

Option D. Pubic symphysis: This is a cartilaginous joint connecting the left and right pubic bones. It is not utilized as a fixation point in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sacrocolpopexy and sacrohysteropexy procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, the mesh is fixed to the sacral promontory, providing strong support to the prolapsed organs.

questions.text: A patient with suicidal tendency ingested some substance. He presents with tachycardia, dilated pupil, and hypertension. Identify the drug. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

The patient's symptoms—tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension—are indicative of a sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is most commonly caused by stimulants like cocaine. Cocaine is a potent sympathomimetic agent that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to increased heart rate (tachycardia), elevated blood pressure (hypertension), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These clinical signs are classic for cocaine toxicity, especially in a setting involving substance use with suicidal intent.

 

Cocaine blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, leading to an excess of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which accounts for the heightened sympathetic activity observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), bradycardia, and respiratory depression. It does not fit the clinical presentation of dilated pupils, tachycardia, and hypertension, which are opposite of opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine, like heroin, is an opioid that causes pupil constriction (miosis) rather than dilation. It also leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure, contrasting the symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Chlorpheniramine: Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that can cause pupil dilation and mild tachycardia, but it is less likely to cause significant hypertension. Furthermore, chlorpheniramine is not commonly associated with substance abuse for suicidal intent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine toxicity is characterized by sympathetic overdrive symptoms such as tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension, making it the likely substance in cases of suspected sympathomimetic drug overdose.

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries.
