questions.text: The longitudinal growth of the bone is affected by fracture of which region of the bone? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Epiphyseal plate

 

The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate or physis, is responsible for the longitudinal growth of long bones in children and adolescents. It consists primarily of cartilage, made up of type II collagen, which progressively ossifies to contribute to the bone's lengthening. This growth plate remains active until it closes after puberty, marking the end of the bone's longitudinal growth. Any fracture affecting this area, such as a Salter-Harris fracture, can disrupt this growth process, potentially leading to growth disturbances or deformities.

 

The other regions of the bone (diaphysis, epiphysis, and metaphysis) are involved in different processes, but they do not directly influence the longitudinal growth as the epiphyseal plate does.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphysis: This is the shaft of the long bone, primarily involved in providing structural support and is not directly responsible for longitudinal growth. Fractures in the diaphysis do not affect the bone's length.

 

Option B. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone, which forms the joint surface. It plays a role in articulating with adjacent bones and, while important for bone structure, it does not contribute directly to longitudinal growth.

 

Option D. Metaphysis: This is the wide portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and the diaphysis. It is highly vascular and is a common site for bone tumors and infections but is not responsible for the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiphyseal plate is the region of the bone responsible for longitudinal growth, and fractures affecting this area can have significant implications on the bone's growth and development.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung Abscess

 

The image shows a cavity in the lung with an air-fluid level, which is characteristic of a lung abscess. A lung abscess typically appears as a localized collection of pus within the lung, caused by microbial infection, and is usually associated with an air-fluid level within a thick-walled cavity. This radiologic appearance is a hallmark of a lung abscess and distinguishes it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculosis can present with thick-walled cavities but typically does not show a distinct air-fluid level as seen in a lung abscess. TB lesions are often more irregular and do not exhibit the same characteristic air-fluid line.

 

Option C. Fungal Pneumonia: Fungal pneumonia often presents with multiple nodules and may display a "halo sign" (nodules surrounded by ground-glass opacity). It does not typically present as a single cavity with an air-fluid level.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition is characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often leading to a visible air-fluid level, but the appearance is generally over a larger portion of the hemithorax and not within a lung cavity itself. It appears more diffuse rather than localized like a lung abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lung abscess is identified by a cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, differentiating it from other pulmonary conditions like TB, fungal infections, and hydropneumothorax.

choices.text: Subintimal lipid infiltration with smooth muscle necrosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with tearing pain in the chest that intensely radiated to his back. He had non-specific ECG changes and his Trop I was negative. During the course of his evaluation he passed away. Biopsy of the aorta obtained during autopsy is shown. What is the likely mechanism behind his disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Connective tissue weakness

 

The clinical presentation (tearing chest pain radiating to the back) and the absence of ECG changes or elevated troponin suggest aortic dissection. The autopsy finding of a split intima further confirms this diagnosis.

 

Aortic dissection occurs when there is a tear in the inner layer (intima) of the aorta, allowing blood to flow between the layers of the aortic wall. The primary underlying cause of aortic dissection is connective tissue weakness in the aortic wall. This weakness can be due to inherited conditions (like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) or other factors like hypertension and aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrinoid necrosis: This is seen in vasculitis and malignant hypertension, but it is not the primary mechanism behind aortic dissection.

 

Option B. Subintimal lipid infiltration with smooth muscle necrosis: This is characteristic of atherosclerosis, which can lead to aneurysms but is not the typical cause of aortic dissection.

 

Option C. Immune complex vasculitis: Vasculitis can weaken the aortic wall, but it is a less common cause of aortic dissection compared to connective tissue weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely mechanism behind aortic dissection is connective tissue weakness in the aortic wall.

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose


In patients with a history of chronic alcohol intake, thiamine deficiency is a common complication. Alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to deficiencies that can impact various metabolic processes, including carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA during glucose metabolism. Administering glucose without prior thiamine can precipitate acute thiamine deficiency symptoms, worsening the patient’s condition and potentially leading to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, a severe neurological disorder.

 

Therefore, in cases where hypoglycemia is present (as indicated by a plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL), the correct management is to first administer thiamine to replenish depleted stores and then follow with dextrose to correct the hypoglycemia safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: While dextrose is necessary to treat hypoglycemia, administering it before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can worsen the deficiency, leading to serious neurological complications.

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is used in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not relevant in alcohol-induced hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine: While thiamine is part of the treatment, it alone does not correct hypoglycemia. Both thiamine and dextrose are necessary, in the correct order.

 

Educational Objective:


In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with hypopyon as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Anterior Uveitis

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the uveal tract of the eye, particularly the anterior segment. It is characterized by the sudden onset of pain, redness, photophobia (difficulty seeing in bright light), and diminished vision. A key finding in this condition is the presence of hypopyon, which is the accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, settling at the bottom.

 

Key clinical signs of Acute Anterior Uveitis includes:

 

1. Hypopyon - The accumulation of white cells (pus) in the anterior chamber.

 

 

2. Circumferential congestion (ciliary flush) - Redness around the corneal edge.

 

 

3. Miotic (small) pupil - A constricted pupil which is not typical in other conditions listed.

 

4. Posterior synechiae, which is an adhesion between the iris and the lens. When attempting to dilate a pupil with posterior synechiae, a festooned (flower-shaped) pupil may result.

 

5. On the corneal endothelium, keratic precipitates (KPs), which are cellular aggregates with protein deposits, are a pathognomonic feature of uveitis.

 

 

6. Painful, diminished vision - Common in inflammatory eye conditions like uveitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: This condition involves elevated intraocular pressure, severe eye pain, and blurred vision. However, the pupil in acute glaucoma is usually mid-dilated and sluggish, not miotic, and hypopyon is not a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option C. Acute Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis primarily affects the conjunctiva, causing redness, irritation, and discharge. Hypopyon is not seen in conjunctivitis, and the condition is not typically associated with severe pain or vision changes seen in uveitis.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episclera, leading to redness and mild discomfort. It usually affects one quadrant and is rarely associated with hypopyon or significant visual symptoms. The pupil size remains normal, and there is no severe pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is characterized by a painful red eye, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a miotic pupil, distinguishing it from other ocular conditions.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with watery diarrhea and vomiting. Electron microscopy showed the following image. Identify the organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

The clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting in a 2-year-old child, combined with the electron microscopy image showing wheel-like structures, strongly indicates Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is easily identified by its characteristic wheel-like appearance under electron microscopy. The virus is known for causing gastroenteritis in infants and young children, leading to dehydration if not managed properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: While adenoviruses can cause gastroenteritis, they do not have the characteristic wheel-like appearance seen in electron microscopy. Adenovirus typically presents with a different capsid morphology that lacks the wheel-like structure of Rotavirus.

 

Option C. Norwalk virus: Also known as Norovirus, this virus is a common cause of gastroenteritis but has a distinct cup-like morphology on electron microscopy, not the wheel-like appearance seen with Rotavirus.

 

Option D. Astrovirus: Astrovirus can cause diarrhea in young children, but it has a star-like appearance under electron microscopy, differing from the wheel-like appearance of Rotavirus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is characterized by its distinctive wheel-like appearance on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a cell is primarily determined by the distribution of ions across the cell membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions. Potassium ions (K+) play the most significant role in establishing the RMP. This is because the cell membrane is more permeable to K+ ions compared to other ions, and there is a higher concentration of K+ inside the cell than outside.

 

The movement of K+ out of the cell down its concentration gradient leads to a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside. This difference in charge across the membrane is what we refer to as the RMP. Other ions, such as sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl-), have some influence, but their impact is much less compared to K+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca2+: Calcium ions have a much smaller role in setting the RMP. They are more involved in processes like muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release rather than in establishing the RMP.

 

Option C. Na+: Sodium ions have a minimal direct role in determining the RMP under normal conditions because the cell membrane is much less permeable to Na+ at rest compared to K+. The Na+/K+ pump helps maintain the gradient of Na+ and K+, but Na+ itself does not significantly influence the RMP.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions can influence the RMP, but their effect is secondary to that of K+. Since the membrane is more permeable to K+, the RMP is predominantly a result of K+ distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Venous ulcer

 

The correct answer is Venous ulcer. Venous ulcers, also known as ulcers of varicose veins, typically occur on the medial aspect of the lower leg, just above the medial malleolus. They are often found in the "gaiter" area and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. The ulcers are usually shallow with irregular borders, and the surrounding skin may show signs of venous stasis, such as hyperpigmentation and edema. The presence of varicose veins and the ulcer's location on the medial side strongly indicate a venous origin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischemic ulcer: Ischemic ulcers are generally located on the tips of toes, pressure points, or other areas that experience reduced blood flow. They have well-defined borders and a punched-out appearance. The location and presentation in this case do not match ischemic ulcers.

 

Option C. Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are usually associated with neuropathy, often seen in diabetic patients. They occur on pressure points such as the plantar surface of the foot and are characterized by a loss of protective sensation. The location above the medial malleolus does not fit with trophic ulcers.

 

Option D.  Infectious ulcer: Infectious ulcers can occur anywhere on the body and are characterized by overt signs of infection like pus, redness, and warmth. While infection can complicate venous ulcers, the primary cause in this case is venous insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

 

Nicotinamide, also known as niacin, is a lipid-lowering agent commonly used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. However, it is associated with several side effects that can limit its use. The most common and characteristic side effect of niacin is flushing, which is caused by the release of prostaglandins. This flushing can be intense and uncomfortable for patients, often leading to discontinuation of the drug.

 

In addition to flushing, niacin can cause hyperuricemia, which may precipitate gout, and it can also lead to hyperglycemia and insulin resistance. Furthermore, niacin is hepatotoxic, which can manifest as elevated liver enzymes.

 

While statins can also cause hyperglycemia and hepatotoxicity, they do not cause the flushing or gout that are characteristic of niacin use. Statins are more commonly associated with myopathy, which is not a feature in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: While atorvastatin, a statin, can cause hyperglycemia and raised liver enzymes, it is not typically associated with flushing or gout. Myopathy is the more significant side effect with statins.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate, used to treat hypertriglyceridemia, may cause elevated liver enzymes and, rarely, hyperuricemia, but it is not associated with flushing or significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that is generally well tolerated and is not associated with the side effects of flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinamide (niacin) is associated with flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, making it the likely cause of these symptoms in a patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text: Identify the procedure based on the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nissen Fundoplication

 

The correct procedure is Nissen Fundoplication. Nissen fundoplication involves a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, which helps prevent gastroesophageal reflux. The image shows a complete wrap around the gastroesophageal junction, characteristic of the Nissen procedure. This procedure is commonly performed to treat severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or hiatal hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toupet Fundoplication: Toupet fundoplication is a partial (270-degree) posterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. This procedure is less constrictive than Nissen fundoplication and is often used in patients with esophageal motility disorders. The image does not depict the 270-degree posterior wrap seen in Toupet fundoplication.

 

Option C. Dor Fundoplication: Dor fundoplication is a partial (180-200 degree) anterior wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus. It is often used as a complementary procedure to surgeries such as Heller myotomy for achalasia. The wrap shown in the image is complete and not partial, ruling out Dor fundoplication.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy: Gastrectomy refers to the surgical removal of part or all of the stomach, often performed for conditions like gastric cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease. The image does not show any removal of stomach tissue, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Nissen Fundoplication is a surgical procedure involving a complete 360-degree wrap of the gastric fundus around the lower esophagus to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. It is distinct from other partial fundoplication techniques such as Toupet and Dor, which involve less than a full wrap.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve. The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department with head trauma due to a road traffic accident. In the hospital, the patient developed seizures. An emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in cases of traumatic brain injury, like the one described. Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient that draws fluid out of the brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space, thereby reducing intracranial pressure and alleviating cerebral edema. This makes it the first-line treatment in emergency situations involving cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron. It is not effective in managing cerebral edema and is primarily used in conditions like heart failure and certain cases of hyperaldosteronism.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is effective in treating peripheral and pulmonary edema by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the loop of Henle. While it is a potent diuretic, it is not the first choice for cerebral edema because it does not effectively lower intracranial pressure as mannitol does.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used mainly for hypertension and mild fluid retention. It is not used in the treatment of cerebral edema and would not be effective in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mannitol is the diuretic of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in emergency settings following traumatic brain injury, due to its ability to reduce intracranial pressure by drawing fluid out of the brain tissue.

questions.text: A female presented with a long history of fever, discolored skin of lower limbs, and lower limb edema. Microscopic examination showed a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial worm responsible for lymphatic filariasis, which often presents with symptoms such as prolonged fever, discolored skin, and limb edema due to lymphatic blockage. Microscopic examination of the organism reveals a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail, which is characteristic of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mansonella: Mansonella species are generally unsheathed microfilariae and do not match the description of having no nuclei at the tail tip, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, is a sheathed microfilaria that has continuous nuclei to the very end of the tail, which distinguishes it from Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Option D. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi is another sheathed filarial worm but is characterized by having nuclei at the tail tip, typically in two distinct spots, unlike Wuchereria bancrofti, which has none.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms of lymphatic filariasis and a sheathed microfilaria with no tail tip nuclei, Wuchereria bancrofti is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A young athlete was diagnosed to have HOCM and has a harsh ejection systolic murmur. Which of the following maneuvers would most likely increase the intensity of the murmur? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valsalva maneuver

 

The intensity of the murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is directly related to the degree of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. The Valsalva maneuver decreases preload (the amount of blood returning to the heart), which in turn, increases the LVOT obstruction and intensifies the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isometric Hand grip: This maneuver increases afterload (the resistance the heart pumps against), which decreases LVOT obstruction and reduces the intensity of the murmur.

 

Option C. Squatting: Squatting increases preload, leading to a decrease in LVOT obstruction and a reduction in the murmur's intensity.

 

Option D. Leaning forward: This maneuver has no significant effect on the hemodynamics of HOCM and thus does not alter the murmur's intensity. It can, however, accentuate the murmur in aortic stenosis by bringing the aortic valve closer to the chest wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HOCM, maneuvers that decrease preload (like the Valsalva maneuver) will increase the intensity of the murmur, while those that increase preload or afterload will decrease it.

questions.text: 2 hours after watching a movie, a patient presented with eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol + Pilocarpine

 

The scenario described is indicative of an acute angle-closure glaucoma attack, which commonly occurs when a person with a shallow anterior chamber enters a dark environment, such as a movie theater. In the dark, the pupil dilates, and the iris moves peripherally, leading to blockage of the trabecular meshwork and subsequently increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition requires urgent management to prevent damage to the optic nerve.

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, is administered to quickly reduce the vitreous volume by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby decreasing IOP. This reduction in vitreous volume allows the lens and iris to move backward, alleviating the blockage of the trabecular meshwork. After the IOP is reduced, Pilocarpine, a miotic agent, is given to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle closure, helping to maintain the IOP at a safer level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mannitol + Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. It has no role in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option C. Mannitol + Atropine: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which would worsen the condition by increasing angle closure. Therefore, it is contraindicated in this scenario.

 

Option D. Mannitol + lubricating eye drops: Lubricating eye drops only provide surface moisture and have no effect on intraocular pressure or the underlying mechanism of angle closure, making them ineffective in this emergency situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves the use of Mannitol to reduce intraocular pressure followed by Pilocarpine to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presented with redness and extreme pain in the eye. There is also diminution of vision and discharge after the use of contact lenses. Which organism can be the causative agent here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a protozoan that commonly infects the cornea, particularly in individuals who misuse contact lenses. It is characterized by severe pain that is disproportionate to the clinical signs observed. This is due to the organism’s tendency to infiltrate perineurally, causing intense pain by involving the corneal nerves.

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis often presents with a ring-shaped corneal ulcer, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

 

The culture medium is non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli.

 

The condition is serious and can lead to severe visual impairment if not treated promptly with appropriate anti-amoebic medications such as Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or Propamidine isethionate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria primarily causes systemic infections and is not typically associated with eye infections or contact lens misuse. It is a less common cause of keratitis and does not present with the severe pain characteristic of Acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of bacterial keratitis, often presenting with redness, discharge, and visual impairment. However, it does not cause the extreme pain seen in Acanthamoeba infections, as it does not infiltrate nerves.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterial pathogen that can cause various infections but is not commonly associated with severe pain and the distinct ring-shaped ulcer seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that exceeds clinical findings and is often associated with contact lens misuse, presenting with a distinctive ring-shaped corneal ulcer.

questions.text: A lady presented with a pelvic mass which was hyperintense on T1-weighted image, hyperintense on T1-fat saturated image, and hypointense on T2-weighted image with T2 shading. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrioma

 

The imaging findings described are characteristic of an endometrioma. Endometriomas are cystic ovarian lesions filled with old blood, often referred to as "chocolate cysts." On MRI, these lesions typically appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images due to the presence of subacute or chronic blood products. On T1-fat saturated images, the mass remains hyperintense, confirming that the hyperintensity is due to blood rather than fat. The hallmark feature of an endometrioma is the T2 shading sign, which refers to the gradual decrease in signal intensity on T2-weighted images due to repeated hemorrhage and layering of blood products within the cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teratoma: Teratomas often contain fat, which would appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images but would become hypointense on T1-fat saturated sequences. The lack of T2 shading and persistence of T1 hyperintensity on fat saturation sequences make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Carcinoma ovary: Carcinoma of the ovary usually appears as a solid or complex cystic mass with variable signal characteristics. It does not typically present with T1 hyperintensity due to fat or blood nor does it show T2 shading.

 

Option D. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are solid ovarian tumors that do not exhibit hyperintensity on T1-weighted images or T2 shading. They usually appear as large, solid masses with homogeneous or slightly heterogeneous signal intensities on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriomas are characterized by T1 hyperintensity that persists on T1-fat saturated images and display the T2 shading sign, distinguishing them from other ovarian masses.

questions.text: There were 4000 live births in a community in a year. Do MMR Calculation if you come to know that 6 women died during pregnancy, labor/delivery, or within 42 days of delivery - 2 due to Obstructed labor, 1 due to Sepsis, 1 due to PPH, 1 due to Snake bite and 1 due to electrocution. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 100

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated using the formula:

 

 

In this scenario, there were 4000 live births in the community.

 

Calculation of Maternal Deaths:

 

  • Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman during pregnancy, labor, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, provided the death is related to maternity or its complications.
  • Out of the 6 reported deaths:
    • 2 deaths due to Obstructed labor (included)
    • 1 death due to Sepsis (included)
    • 1 death due to PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) (included)
    • 1 death due to Snake bite (not related to maternity, hence excluded)
    • 1 death due to Electrocution (not related to maternity, hence excluded)

 

Therefore, only 4 deaths are considered maternal deaths.

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, considering only deaths directly related to pregnancy or its complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with acute epigastric pain and nausea. Lab reports showed an increase in serum lipase levels. He received 2L of fluids during admission, and three days after stabilization, he developed sudden breathlessness. Chest X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

 

The patient’s presentation with acute epigastric pain, nausea, and elevated lipase levels suggests acute pancreatitis. The development of sudden breathlessness and the presence of bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, in the setting of pancreatitis, is highly indicative of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), a form of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. ARDS is a severe complication associated with acute pancreatitis and is characterized by bilateral infiltrates on imaging, often symmetric, without evidence of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased PCWP: An increased Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure (PCWP) suggests cardiogenic pulmonary edema, typically seen in heart failure, not ARDS. In ARDS, PCWP is normal or low, as the edema is non-cardiogenic.

 

Option B. Pulmonary thromboembolism: Pulmonary thromboembolism usually presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and possibly hemoptysis, but it does not typically cause bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray as seen here.

 

Option D. Aspiration pneumonitis: Aspiration pneumonitis commonly causes unilateral infiltrates initially, especially in the right lower lobe, due to the anatomical position of the bronchus. While aspiration can progress to ARDS, the history provided does not suggest aspiration, making it an unlikely primary diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARDS is a potential severe complication of acute pancreatitis, presenting with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema characterized by bilateral infiltrates and normal PCWP

questions.text: Arrange the steps of the Disaster cycle in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation  

 

The disaster cycle outlines the sequential steps taken in response to a disaster and how communities can prepare and recover from such events. The correct sequence is:

 

  1. Disaster Impact: This is the immediate occurrence of the disaster event, such as an earthquake, flood, or hurricane, leading to direct damage and disruption.
  2. Response: Following the impact, emergency measures are taken to save lives, provide first aid, conduct search and rescue, and offer immediate relief such as food, shelter, and medical treatment.
  3. Rehabilitation: After the initial response, efforts shift to restoring essential services and helping affected communities return to normal. This involves rebuilding infrastructure, ensuring public health, and restoring social and economic activities.
  4. Mitigation: This final step involves implementing measures to reduce the severity of future disasters. This can include building stronger infrastructure, improving disaster preparedness plans, and promoting community awareness to minimize potential damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the disaster cycle is: Disaster Impact → Response → Rehabilitation → Mitigation.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the association between the consumption of vegetarian/non-vegetarian food with certain diseases. The incidence of disease was evaluated in those two groups. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used when evaluating the association between categorical variables, such as the consumption of vegetarian or non-vegetarian food and the incidence of certain diseases. This study involves comparing the occurrence of diseases in two groups (vegetarians vs. non-vegetarians), which represents qualitative data.

 

The Chi-square test is specifically designed for non-parametric data (data that does not follow a normal distribution) and is ideal for comparing proportions, percentages, or counts between two or more groups. In this context, the test helps determine whether there is a significant association between diet type and disease occurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Paired student’s t-test: The paired student’s t-test is used for comparing means within the same group at two different times (before and after an intervention). It is suitable for continuous data, not for comparing categorical data between two distinct groups.

 

Option B. Unpaired student’s t-test: The unpaired student’s t-test compares the means of two independent groups, such as test scores or measurements. This test is used for continuous, normally distributed data and is not suitable for categorical or qualitative data like the incidence of diseases.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric test used for comparing two paired groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is similar to the paired t-test but for ordinal or continuous data, making it unsuitable for categorical data such as disease incidence.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chi-square test is used to determine the association between categorical variables, especially when comparing the incidence of outcomes across two or more independent groups.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I
Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

questions.text: Following ovulation, the oocyte remains halted in which meiotic phase until fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

 

After ovulation, the oocyte that is released is the secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis. This arrest continues until fertilization occurs. During fertilization, the entry of sperm triggers the completion of meiosis II, leading to the formation of a mature ovum and the release of the second polar body.

 

This arrest in metaphase II is a crucial step in the reproductive cycle, ensuring that the oocyte is ready to complete meiosis only if fertilization occurs, which prevents the wasteful completion of meiosis without fertilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I: This phase describes the primary oocyte that is arrested in prophase I during fetal development and remains in this state until puberty. It is not involved in the post-ovulation phase.

 

Option B. Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II: This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte does not complete prophase II. It arrests in metaphase II after ovulation and only completes meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

 

Option C. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not arrest in prophase II. It arrests in prophase I, and after puberty, it resumes meiosis to form a secondary oocyte.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II at the time of ovulation and remains in this stage until fertilization occurs, highlighting a critical regulatory checkpoint in the female reproductive cycle.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a greyish white membrane over tonsils and presented with bull-neck appearance. She has a 2-year-old brother who is fully immunized for his age. What should be given to the brother? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Nothing should be given

 

The 5-year-old girl shows clinical signs of diphtheria, characterized by a greyish white membrane over the tonsils and bull-neck appearance. The question asks about the appropriate management for her fully immunized 2-year-old brother, who is a close contact.

 

 

For contacts of a diphtheria case:

 

  • If the contact (in this case, the brother) has received primary immunization or a booster within the last 2 years, no additional intervention is needed.
  • If the immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, then a booster dose is required to maintain protection.
  • If the contact is completely unimmunized – Prophylactic t/t with Penicillin or Erythromycin along with 1000-2000 units Diphtheria antitoxin, and start immunization of contact

 

Medical surveillance needs to be done daily and

 

Bacteriological surveillance – swabs on weekly basis 

 

Since the brother is fully immunized for his age, and presumably within the past 2 years, no additional treatment is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillin:  This is used as prophylactic treatment for contacts who are completely unimmunized. It is not indicated for those who are fully vaccinated.

 

Option C.  Diphtheria antitoxin: This is administered to unimmunized contacts for immediate passive immunity, especially when there is a high risk of exposure, but it is not required for fully immunized individuals.

 

Option D.  1 dose of DPT booster:  This is given if the last dose of primary immunization or booster was taken more than 2 years ago, but not needed if within the last 2 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In managing contacts of diphtheria, no additional doses are required if the contact has received primary immunization or booster within the last 2 years.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroid


The image shows a well-circumscribed, whitish lesion within the uterine cavity, which is characteristic of a submucosal fibroid. Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can present as distinct, well-defined lesions that are separate from the normal myometrial tissue, often appearing white or light in color compared to the surrounding pink myometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Adenomyosis:  is incorrect because adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged and diffusely thickened uterus without distinct, well-defined lesions.

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp:  is incorrect as polyps are usually small, soft, and protruding growths that arise from the endometrial lining. They do not appear as a well-defined, firm, and large mass like the fibroid shown.

 

Option D. Endometrial cancer: is incorrect because endometrial cancer typically presents as irregular, vascular, and possibly friable growths within the uterine cavity, not as a smooth, well-defined mass.

 

Educational Objective:


Fibroids are well-defined, circumscribed lesions within the uterine cavity that are distinct in color and structure compared to surrounding myometrial tissue, distinguishing them from other uterine conditions like adenomyosis, polyps, and cancer.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Abscess

 

The provided MRI images show a ring-enhancing lesion with bright white areas on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), which indicates diffusion restriction. Diffusion restriction on DWI is characteristic of a brain abscess. Brain abscesses typically appear as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction due to the presence of pus, which restricts the movement of water molecules. The absence of bony structures and clear visualization of the brain on the MRI sequence also confirm that this is a DWI image, where bright areas represent restricted diffusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculomas: Tuberculomas often present as multiple ring-enhancing lesions that may conglomerate, and do not show the same characteristic diffusion restriction seen in abscesses. They have a different imaging pattern and usually do not exhibit a single, well-defined ring-enhancing lesion with prominent diffusion restriction.

 

Option C. Cryptococcomas: These lesions are commonly found in the basal ganglia and have a soap-bubble appearance rather than a ring enhancement. Cryptococcomas are typically not associated with the intense diffusion restriction seen in abscesses.

 

Option D. NCC (Neurocysticercosis): NCC lesions often have a characteristic central scolex, which is not visible in this image. The presence of a scolex is a key feature for diagnosing NCC, and the absence of this finding makes NCC less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain abscesses present as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), appearing bright white on DWI due to restricted water movement caused by pus accumulation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and horizontal gaze palsy. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is most consistent with the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Foville syndrome

 

Foville syndrome is a brainstem stroke syndrome characterized by contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body) and ipsilateral cranial nerve palsies, specifically involving cranial nerves VI (abducens nerve) and VII (facial nerve), as well as horizontal gaze palsy due to involvement of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) or medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The combination of left-sided hemiparesis, right-sided facial paralysis, and horizontal gaze palsy is classical for Foville syndrome, making it the correct diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Locked In syndrome: This syndrome results from a lesion in the ventral pons, leading to quadriparesis (paralysis of all four limbs) and loss of voluntary movement except for vertical eye movements and blinking. It does not match the presentation of unilateral weakness with specific cranial nerve involvement.

 

Option C. Millard-Gubler syndrome: This syndrome involves contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral cranial nerve VI (abducens nerve) and VII (facial nerve) palsy but does not present with horizontal gaze palsy, which is the key differentiating feature from Foville syndrome.

 

Option D. Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as lateral medullary syndrome, Wallenberg syndrome primarily involves sensory deficits, including pain and temperature loss on one side of the face and the opposite side of the body. It does not typically involve significant motor weakness or cranial nerve VI or VII palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foville syndrome involves contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral cranial nerve palsies, and horizontal gaze palsy due to brainstem involvement, distinguishing it from other stroke syndromes.

questions.text: A patient presents with a perforation in the tympanic membrane. During the evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What is the expected outcome of the Rinne test in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative

 

Perforation of the tympanic membrane results in conductive hearing loss because the sound waves cannot be properly transmitted through the middle ear. In cases of conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), will be negative. This occurs because bone conduction is perceived as louder than air conduction, indicating a conductive defect. The negative Rinne test is characteristic of any lesion or abnormality affecting the external ear, tympanic membrane, or middle ear, as these structures are responsible for sound conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive: A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is louder than bone conduction, which is normal or seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss like that caused by a tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The Rinne test is typically either positive or negative, and "indeterminate" does not correctly describe the results related to tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal Rinne test result suggests equal loudness of air and bone conduction, which is not typically associated with tympanic membrane perforation. This term is not commonly used in describing Rinne test outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A perforation in the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is heard louder than air conduction.

questions.text: A young male came with GI complaints like malabsorption, diarrhea. Cutaneous examination noted itchy lesions on the skin with blistering. On histopathology, cryptitis and flattened villi were noted. His condition improved with a gluten-free diet. What is the specific antibody in this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tissue Transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3)

 

The patient's symptoms, including gastrointestinal complaints like malabsorption and diarrhea, combined with itchy skin lesions and histopathological findings of cryptitis and flattened villi, are indicative of dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

 

The specific antibody associated with dermatitis herpetiformis is tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3). This antibody is primarily responsible for the characteristic skin lesions seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibodies: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are a group of autoantibodies that target components of the cell nucleus. They are commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions but are not related to celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3) antibodies is a hallmark of dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease. This autoimmune response is triggered by gluten ingestion and manifests with both gastrointestinal and cutaneous symptoms.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

 

Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. In this case, the patient presents with massive splenomegaly, fever, anemia, and other features suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India. The vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania is the Phlebotomus species, commonly known as sandflies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rat fly: Rat flies are not vectors for Leishmania. They are typically associated with the spread of different diseases, like murine typhus, but not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Chrysops fly: Chrysops flies are known as deer flies and are vectors for diseases like Loiasis but are not involved in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Option D. Black fly: Black flies are vectors for Onchocerciasis (river blindness) and have no role in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clonidine

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension. One of the common side effects of Clonidine includes dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, which matches the symptoms described in this case. Additionally, a significant risk associated with Clonidine is the potential for rebound hypertension if the medication is suddenly discontinued, as can happen if a dose is missed. This rebound effect occurs because the body's sympathetic nervous system experiences a sudden surge in activity once the inhibitory effects of Clonidine are removed, leading to a hypertensive emergency, as seen in this patient.

 

Remember – Clonidine is safe in Pregnancy 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension but does not typically cause rebound hypertension. Its side effects more commonly include peripheral edema rather than the symptoms described here.

 

Option C. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that does not cause the described side effects of dry mouth, dizziness, and constipation. Additionally, sudden discontinuation of Lisinopril does not lead to a hypertensive emergency.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). It generally does not cause dry mouth, constipation, or dizziness, and discontinuation does not lead to rebound hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine is an antihypertensive medication that can cause dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, and sudden discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, making it crucial for patients to maintain consistent dosing.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astemizole

 

Astemizole is an antihistamine known to cause QT prolongation and an increased risk of Torsades de pointes, especially when combined with other medications that affect cardiac conduction, such as erythromycin. This dangerous interaction occurs because both drugs can interfere with cardiac potassium channels, prolonging the QT interval and predisposing the patient to potentially fatal arrhythmias.

 

Astemizole and terfenadine are notable among antihistamines for their high risk of causing Torsades de pointes, which has led to the withdrawal of terfenadine from the market. Astemizole, though less commonly used, still poses a significant risk when combined with drugs like erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that does not significantly affect the QT interval and is not associated with Torsades de pointes when combined with erythromycin.

 

Option C. Loratadine: Loratadine is another second-generation antihistamine with a good safety profile concerning cardiac conduction and QT interval prolongation, making it a safer choice in patients requiring antihistamine treatment.

 

Option D. Promethazine: Although promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine, it does not carry the same risk of QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes as astemizole when used with erythromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Astemizole, when combined with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes due to its significant effect on cardiac potassium channels, posing a high risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. The child has no significant past medical history. On examination, the heart rate is 220 beats per minute, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and the child appears anxious but is otherwise stable. An ECG confirms the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). What is the initial recommended dose of adenosine for this child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.1 mg/kg

 

In the treatment of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in children, the initial recommended dose of adenosine is 0.1 mg/kg administered intravenously. This dose is given as a rapid IV push and is often followed by a saline flush to ensure that the drug reaches the heart quickly. The maximum initial dose should not exceed 6 mg. If the first dose is ineffective, a second dose can be administered at 0.2 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 12 mg.

 

Adenosine works by transiently blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which helps to terminate the reentrant circuit responsible for PSVT. It is the first-line treatment for PSVT due to its quick onset of action and short half-life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial recommended dose of adenosine for treating PSVT in children is 0.1 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 6 mg. If the initial dose is ineffective, a higher dose of 0.2 mg/kg may be administered.

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented for evaluation. During the session, he was quite charming, and there is a history of him behaving nicely with family members. However, he often gets in fights with friends. He was also involved in multiple police cases. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antisocial personality

 

The description provided in the question fits the criteria for Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). Key characteristics of ASPD include a disregard for others' rights, frequent conflicts with social norms, legal issues, and manipulative or deceitful behavior. This individual displays charm during sessions, which is common among people with antisocial personality, as they can be superficially charming and convincing. The fact that he is often involved in fights and has multiple police cases further supports the diagnosis of ASPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Narcissistic personality: Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by grandiosity, a constant need for admiration, and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often talk about themselves, praise themselves excessively, and have a sense of entitlement. This patient's behavior does not include any such characteristics; instead, it focuses on antisocial behaviors.

 

Option C. Schizotypal personality: Schizotypal Personality Disorder is marked by eccentric behavior, discomfort with close relationships, and cognitive or perceptual distortions. There is no evidence in the question indicating any such traits, such as odd beliefs, social anxiety, or unusual thinking.

 

Option D. Paranoid personality: Paranoid Personality Disorder involves a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others. People with this disorder frequently believe others are out to harm or deceive them. This patient shows no signs of suspiciousness or paranoia; his behavior is more aligned with antisocial conduct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of disregard for others' rights, often involving legal issues, deceitful behavior, and superficial charm.

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioides immitis exists as spherules filled with endospores in tissue, not as budding yeast. It is endemic to the southwestern United States, especially Arizona and California.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: Implantation of the embryo takes place how many days after fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8


Implantation of the embryo typically starts around 5 to 6 days after fertilization and is usually completed by 8 to 9 days. After fertilization, the embryo undergoes several stages of development, including cleavage and blastocyst formation. The blastocyst travels down the fallopian tube and reaches the uterus by around day 5. It then begins to attach to and invade the uterine lining, completing the implantation process by around day 8. Therefore, 8 days is the most accurate answer representing the completion of the implantation process.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Implantation of the embryo begins around day 5 to 6 and is completed by day 8 to 9 after fertilization.

questions.text: What is the most common anatomical site for a congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterolateral


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral aspect of the diaphragm, specifically on the left side. This type of hernia is known as the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs due to a failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close properly during fetal development. This defect typically occurs on the left side because the liver provides a protective barrier on the right, making right-sided defects less common. Bochdalek hernias account for the majority of congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterolateral: This location is associated with Morgagni hernia, which is less common and usually occurs on the right side near the sternum. It does not typically involve the posterolateral region, making it a less frequent site for congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Option B. Central tendon: The central tendon of the diaphragm does not commonly present with congenital hernias, as it is primarily a strong fibrous part of the diaphragm, less prone to defects.

 

Option C. Crural: Crural defects are not commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernias. These defects would more likely involve esophageal hernias rather than congenital diaphragmatic hernias.

 

Educational Objective:


The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the posterolateral region, predominantly on the left side, known as the Bochdalek hernia.

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks, especially in cases of substantial fetal anomalies, a medical board is constituted. This board typically includes specialists relevant to the condition and the required medical care. The standard members include: Radiologist, Gynecologist and Pediatrician.

 

A legal advisor is not a part of this medical board, as the board's purpose is to provide medical, not legal, expertise. The fourth member is often a specialist relevant to the detected anomaly rather than a legal professional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiologist: Included to assess fetal abnormalities through imaging and provide critical information about the anomaly.

 

Option B. Gynecologist: A core member who handles the MTP procedure and provides obstetric and gynecological care.

 

Option D. Pediatrician: Included to give an opinion on the implications of fetal anomalies and expected postnatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

questions.text: Patient with high triglycerides esterified with long chain fatty acid (LCFA) presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Carnitine deficiency is a condition in which there is insufficient carnitine to transport long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation, which is the process that generates energy from fats. As a result, LCFAs cannot be oxidized and accumulate in tissues, leading to fatigue, muscle weakness, and the presence of fat vacuoles on muscle biopsy. The accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids is characteristic of carnitine deficiency because LCFAs bind to glycerol when they are not oxidized. This condition often presents with symptoms such as exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and, in severe cases, rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FA synthase defect: Fatty acid synthase (FAS) is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of fatty acids in the body. A defect in FAS usually does not present with the clinical picture seen here since fatty acids can be provided through the diet. It is often benign and does not lead to the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscles or the described clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. LPL defect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) into free fatty acids for tissue uptake. An LPL defect leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated triglycerides, pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas, which do not match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Option D. LDL receptor defect: A defect in the LDL receptor results in type 2a hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol levels, tendon xanthomas, and a higher risk of atherosclerosis. This condition does not involve the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscle or present with fatigue related to long-chain fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Deficiency in carnitine leads to the accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids in muscle tissues, causing fatigue and exercise intolerance

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amyloid beta plaque

 

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of senile dementia, characterized by the accumulation of amyloid beta plaques in the brain. These plaques are abnormal clumps of protein that disrupt cell function and are a hallmark of Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

The presence of amyloid beta plaques contributes to neurodegeneration, synaptic dysfunction, and cognitive decline observed in Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha synuclein: This protein is associated with Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia, where it forms abnormal aggregates called Lewy bodies. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option C. Glial fibrillary associated protein: This protein is found in astrocytes and is commonly associated with gliosis, not specifically with Alzheimer’s disease. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Option D. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found in muscle tissue and is related to muscle disorders, not neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid beta plaque is a key pathological marker of Alzheimer’s disease, contributing significantly to the neurodegenerative changes seen in this condition.

questions.text: Identify the brain malformation shown in the given MRI image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arnold Chiari malformation

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is a condition where there is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellum, particularly the tonsils, which can be observed on MRI scans as a distinctive pattern of herniation below the level of the foramen magnum. The provided radiograph shows this exact presentation, with cerebellar tissue extending through the foramen magnum, indicating Arnold Chiari malformation.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosal agenesis: This condition involves the complete or partial absence of the corpus callosum, the structure that connects the two cerebral hemispheres. This malformation would not present with cerebellar herniation on imaging but would show an absence of the corpus callosum on MRI.

 

Option B. Vein of Galen malformation: This is a vascular malformation involving an abnormal connection between cerebral arteries and veins. It would appear as a large, dilated venous structure on imaging and would not show herniation of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, partial or complete absence of the cerebellar vermis, and enlargement of the posterior fossa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is identified by the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, visible on MRI scans as the downward displacement of cerebellar tissue.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle partially spared in a patient who presented with sciatica and tender hamstrings? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obturator nerve

 

The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle in the medial compartment of the thigh, which is partially spared in cases of sciatica due to its dual nerve supply. The adductor magnus has two heads: the ischial head (hamstring part) and the pubic head (adductor part). The adductor part is supplied by the obturator nerve, while the hamstring part is supplied by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve. In patients with sciatica, the obturator nerve can still supply the adductor part of the adductor magnus, leading to partial sparing of muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common peroneal nerve: This nerve supplies muscles in the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg and does not innervate the adductor magnus or any muscles in the medial thigh.

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: This nerve primarily supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh, including muscles like the quadriceps femoris, and does not innervate the adductor magnus.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Although the tibial nerve supplies the hamstring part of the adductor magnus, it is affected in sciatica, leading to the involvement of muscles it innervates, unlike the obturator nerve which partially spares the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quick revision of the hybrid muscles of the upper and lower limbs:

questions.text: Identify the mediastinal mass shown in the image. The measured Hounsfield unit in the mass revealed -70 HU. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teratoma

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) measurement of -70 indicates that the mass contains fat, as fat typically has an HU range between -10 and -100. The presence of negative HU values suggests that the mass is darker than water, which has an HU of zero. Among the listed options, teratomas are known to contain macroscopic fat and calcifications, which are characteristic features. These findings align with the imaging characteristics of teratomas, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:
