Option A. Thymoma: Thymomas usually appear as soft tissue masses without fat content and do not typically exhibit negative HU values. They lack the calcification and macroscopic fat seen in teratomas.

 

Option B. PTH adenoma: Parathyroid (PTH) adenomas are soft tissue lesions usually found in the neck region and do not exhibit fat-containing characteristics or negative HU values on imaging.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: Lymphomas typically present as homogenous, soft tissue masses without fat content or calcifications. They also do not show negative HU values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative Hounsfield Unit values (between -10 to -100) indicate the presence of fat within a lesion, suggesting that the mass could be a teratoma, especially when accompanied by calcifications.

questions.text: A patient had a blunt injury to the abdomen after an RTA and underwent ileal resection. He recovered well post-surgery but months later presents with fatigue and exercise intolerance. Which of the following will not be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microcytic hypochromic anemia

 

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to impaired absorption. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytosis). Microcytic hypochromic anemia, on the other hand, is characterized by small, pale red blood cells and is typically associated with iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytonuclear dyssynchrony: This refers to the asynchronous maturation of the nucleus and cytoplasm in red blood cells, a characteristic feature of megaloblastic anemia seen in B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Romberg's sign positive: This indicates impaired proprioception, which can be a manifestation of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, a neurological complication of B12 deficiency

 

Option D. Subacute combined degeneration: This is a demyelinating disease of the spinal cord that can occur due to B12 deficiency, leading to neurological symptoms like impaired proprioception and gait disturbances

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, which manifests as megaloblastic anemia (macrocytic) and neurological symptoms like subacute combined degeneration.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of vesicular oral lesions, and on skin sample, DIF showed a fishnet pattern as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the formation of vesicles and bullae, particularly on mucous membranes such as the oral cavity. The disease is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins (desmosomal proteins) that hold keratinocytes together. This results in acantholysis, where keratinocytes lose their adhesion, leading to intraepidermal blister formation.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of a biopsy from perilesional skin in pemphigus vulgaris typically shows a "fishnet" or "chicken wire" pattern, which is due to the deposition of IgG antibodies along the keratinocyte cell membranes. The image provided in the question clearly demonstrates this characteristic pattern, which is pathognomonic for pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bullous pemphigoid: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder, but it primarily affects older adults and presents with subepidermal blisters rather than intraepidermal ones. The DIF pattern in bullous pemphigoid typically shows a linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Option C. LIGA: This option seems to be a distractor as there is no recognized dermatological condition by this acronym. This might be a typographical error or a non-standard term, hence it is not relevant to this question.

 

Option D. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This is a chronic blistering skin condition associated with gluten sensitivity (celiac disease). The DIF pattern in dermatitis herpetiformis typically shows granular deposits of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with a characteristic "fishnet" pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition along keratinocyte cell membranes. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

Option 'A' is the correct answer because it shows the characteristic yellowish pseudomembrane along with ulcers, which are key indicators of pseudomembranous colitis. This condition is typically caused by an overgrowth of Clostridium difficile bacteria, often following antibiotic use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This image is suggestive of feline esophagitis, often associated with eosinophilic esophagitis, due to the presence of inflammation and possibly eosinophilic infiltrates in the esophagus.

 

Option C: This image depicts diverticulosis, characterized by the presence of small pouches (diverticula) protruding from the colon wall.

 

Option D: This image is suggestive of cancer or malignancy due to the presence of a distinct mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomembranous colitis is characterized by the presence of yellowish pseudomembranes and ulcers in the colon, often caused by Clostridium difficile overgrowth.

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Homonymous hemianopia

 

The image shows a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision on the right side of the visual field in both eyes, which is termed as homonymous hemianopia. The term "homonymous" indicates that the defect is on the same side of the visual field in both eyes, while "hemianopia" refers to the loss of half of the visual field.

 

This pattern is typically caused by a lesion in the left optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe, which affects the visual field on the opposite side (right side in this case). The defect is contralateral to the side of the lesion, meaning that a left-sided lesion will produce a right-sided visual field loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopia: This condition involves the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, usually due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as from a pituitary tumor. The image does not show this pattern, as only the right visual fields are affected, not the outer fields.

 

Option B. Binasal hemianopia: This defect involves the loss of vision in the nasal (inner) fields of both eyes, often resulting from bilateral optic nerve compression. The visual defect in the image does not match this pattern, as it shows only right-sided field loss.

 

Option C. Altitudinal defect: This type of defect affects the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes, commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy. The image does not depict an upper or lower field defect; rather, it shows a loss on the right side of both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: A patient present at 10 weeks pregnancy. She asks for medical method of abortion. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mifepristone and misoprostol

 

The Ans. is Mifepristone and misoprostol. Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) using mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for up to 12 weeks of gestation as per the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines.

 

 While the Government of India allows medical abortion up to 9 weeks, the WHO supports the use of this regimen until 12 weeks, though the likelihood of failure increases slightly as the gestational age advances. Mifepristone is an anti-progestin that primes the uterus, and misoprostol, a prostaglandin, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. This combination is effective and widely used in the first trimester and can also be employed in the second trimester with adjustments in misoprostol dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperosmolar saline: This is an outdated method and primarily used in the second trimester. It is not recommended for first-trimester abortions due to associated risks and inefficacy compared to current medical regimens.

 

Option C. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is primarily used to induce labor in the second or third trimester. It is not effective or commonly used for first-trimester medical abortions due to its different mechanism of action and limited efficacy in early gestation.

 

Option D. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a prostaglandin used primarily for cervical ripening and labor induction in the third trimester. It is not suitable for first-trimester medical abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a medical abortion at 10 weeks, the recommended regimen is mifepristone followed by misoprostol, as it is effective and safe up to 12 weeks of gestation according to WHO guidelines.

choices.text: Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present
Conscious with Pulse present Breathing present

questions.text: This position is given in which patients? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present

 

The position shown in the image is the recovery position. This position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing adequately. The purpose of placing a patient in the recovery position is to maintain a clear airway and prevent aspiration by allowing any fluids (like saliva or vomit) to drain from the mouth. This position also helps prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse absent, Breathing present: If a patient is pulseless, they are in cardiac arrest and require immediate CPR, not placement in the recovery position.

 

Option B. Pulse absent, Breathing absent: In the absence of both pulse and breathing, the patient requires immediate CPR and advanced life support, not the recovery position.

 

Option D. Conscious with Pulse present, Breathing present: A conscious patient who is breathing and has a pulse would not need to be placed in the recovery position. They should be kept comfortable and monitored, but no special positioning is necessary unless they become unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing, to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

questions.text: An infectious disease has its incubation period as 5-14 days, with its median incubation period being 10 days. The quarantine of contacts traveling to a new country should be done for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 14 days


Quarantine is the process of separating and restricting the movement of healthy individuals who may have been exposed to an infectious disease, to prevent its spread. Quarantine is typically implemented for the maximum incubation period of the disease, which is the time between exposure to the infection and the onset of symptoms.

 

In this case, the maximum incubation period is 14 days. Therefore, quarantine should be conducted for 14 days to ensure that if symptoms develop, they will appear within this period, confirming the need for isolation and treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quarantine should be conducted for the maximum incubation period of the infectious disease to ensure that symptoms will manifest within that time, confirming whether a contact becomes a case.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of classic galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, which causes toxicity, especially in the liver, kidney, and lens of the eye.

 

The symptoms presented in the question are early cataract, refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis—are typical of galactosemia. The cataract seen in these patients is often described as an "," which is due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, a metabolite of galactose.

 

 

Galactosemia can be of three types:

 

  • Type 1: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (most common and severe form).
  • Type 2: Galactokinase deficiency.
  • Type 3: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency.

 

Among these, Type 1 galactosemia (GALT deficiency) is responsible for the symptoms described and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is not associated with galactose metabolism or the symptoms described, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol in the lens, contributing to cataract formation in patients with galactosemia. However, the enzyme's deficiency is not the primary cause of the described condition; instead, its action exacerbates the effects of galactosemia.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the phosphorylation of glucose, not galactose. It plays no direct role in the pathogenesis of galactosemia or the symptoms mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative
Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive

questions.text: A 30-year-old man had an episode of jaundice due to HBV one year back. On follow-up now, he has normal levels of liver enzymes. His current profile is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis for his current condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive


The patient had jaundice due to Hepatitis B one year ago and now presents with persistent Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), which is visible in the profile as the orange line indicating ongoing infection. According to the definition, Chronic Hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months. In this case, the presence of HBeAg (Hepatitis B e-antigen) positivity indicates active viral replication and higher infectivity, confirming the diagnosis of chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative: This condition involves the persistence of HBsAg but without the presence of HBeAg. The patient’s profile shows HBeAg positivity, ruling out this option.

 

Option C. Resolved infection: Resolved infection would be characterized by the disappearance of HBsAg and the presence of anti-HBs antibodies. The patient’s profile still shows HBsAg, indicating ongoing infection.

 

Option D. Acute Hepatitis B: Acute Hepatitis B would occur within the first six months of infection. Given that the infection has persisted for over a year, this is a chronic condition.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic Hepatitis B is defined by the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months. The presence of HBeAg indicates active viral replication, characterizing the infection as HBeAg positive.

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic pancreatitis

 

Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by the presence of calcifications along the pancreas, which is a hallmark sign visible on imaging. The X-ray shows calcification along the pancreas, which is indicative of chronic inflammation and fibrosis due to ongoing damage to the pancreatic tissue. These calcifications are a classic sign of chronic pancreatitis and help differentiate it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman disease: Wolman disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by calcifications in the adrenal glands due to a deficiency in lysosomal acid lipase. The calcifications in Wolman disease appear near the adrenal glands, which are located superiorly to the kidneys, rather than along the pancreas.

 

Option C. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis typically presents with inflammation of the pancreas but does not usually involve calcification. Acute cases are seen with other signs of inflammation like fluid collections but not chronic calcifications.

 

Option D. TB Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis rarely shows calcification on a plain abdominal X-ray unless there is involvement of specific abdominal lymph nodes or organ involvement like the adrenal glands. Pancreatic calcification is not a typical feature of TB.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by pancreatic calcifications on imaging, which are absent in acute pancreatitis and other conditions like Wolman disease or TB.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lachman’s test

 

The image shows the examiner performing a test where the knee is placed in 20 to 30 degrees of flexion and the tibia is pulled anteriorly. This describes the Lachman’s test, which is used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).

 

  • The Lachman’s test is preferred over the anterior drawer test for diagnosing ACL injuries because it can be performed with the knee in slight flexion, which isolates the ACL and reduces the influence of other structures. A positive Lachman’s test, indicated by increased anterior movement of the tibia relative to the femur, suggests an ACL tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior drawer test: The anterior drawer test is also used to assess ACL injuries but differs from the Lachman’s test in that the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. In the anterior drawer test, the examiner pulls the tibia forward while stabilizing the leg, but this test can be less sensitive than the Lachman’s test in acute injuries.

 

Option C. McMurray’s test: McMurray’s test is used to evaluate meniscal injuries, not ligamentous injuries. It involves flexing the knee and applying rotational forces to check for a meniscal tear. It is done with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion and involves listening for clicking or popping sounds in the meniscus.

 

Option D. Posterior drawer test: The posterior drawer test is used to assess the integrity of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). It is performed with the knee at 90 degrees of flexion, and the examiner pushes the tibia backward. This is not the test being performed in the image, as the tibia is being pulled anteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lachman’s test is the most reliable physical exam maneuver for diagnosing ACL tears, performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion.

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: Identify the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bier’s block

 

The image depicts the setup for a Bier’s block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA).

 

This technique is commonly used for short surgical procedures on the extremities, such as the hands or forearms.

 

The process involves placing a double cuff tourniquet on the limb to occlude blood flow, then injecting a local anesthetic (such as lidocaine) into a vein in the isolated limb.

 

The tourniquet prevents the anesthetic from circulating out of the limb, thus providing anesthesia to the area. Bier's block is a fast and effective method for producing anesthesia in a limb without the need for general anesthesia or nerve blocks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve block: A radial nerve block involves injecting anesthetic near the radial nerve . It does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection of local anesthetic as depicted in the image.

 

Option B. Axillary block: An axillary block is a type of brachial plexus block where anesthetic is injected near the axillary artery to block the nerves supplying the upper limb.

 

Option D. Wrist block: A wrist block involves injecting local anesthetic near the nerves at the wrist to provide anesthesia to the hand. It is different from Bier's block and does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection as shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bier’s block, or intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), is used for anesthetizing a limb by injecting local anesthetic into a vein while using a tourniquet to confine the anesthetic to the limb.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby presented with the following symptoms. What is the ideal treatment for the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate surgery

 

The image shows a 2-month-old baby with leukocoria, which refers to a white reflection in the pupil. The differential diagnoses for a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria include congenital cataract and congenital glaucoma. In both cases, surgery is the definitive treatment.

 

Congenital cataract is more likely in this scenario as the whiteness is confined to the pupil, whereas congenital glaucoma typically causes the entire cornea to appear hazy.

 

 

 

In both the condition, Immediate surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications like stimulus deprivation amblyopia, which can lead to permanent vision impairment if treatment is delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First try medical management: Medical management is primarily used to manage congenital glaucoma temporarily until surgery can be performed. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, immediate surgery is necessary.

 

Option C. Surgery after 2 years: Delaying surgery to 2 years increases the risk of amblyopia, a condition where the brain starts ignoring signals from the affected eye, leading to vision loss.

 

Option D. Surgery after 6 months of age: Postponing surgery to 6 months also poses a high risk of developing amblyopia, as early surgical intervention is critical to ensure normal visual development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 2-month-old presenting with leukocoria, immediate surgery is the ideal treatment to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development.

questions.text:
Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024)

 

 

 

  1. CA 125
  2. LDH
  3. AFP
  4. hCG
  5. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5


The ultrasound image shows an ovarian mass, and various tumor markers are used in the evaluation of ovarian tumors to help in diagnosis and management:

 

  1. CA 125: This is primarily used as a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, especially serous cystadenocarcinoma. Elevated levels of CA 125 are often associated with advanced stages of the disease.
  2. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): This marker is associated with dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. Elevated LDH levels can suggest the presence of this tumor.
  3. AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein): AFP is a marker used for yolk sac tumors, which are rare but aggressive ovarian germ cell tumors.
  4. hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): hCG is elevated in cases of non-gestational choriocarcinoma, which is another form of germ cell tumor.
  5. CA 19-9: This tumor marker is associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, a type of ovarian epithelial tumor. It is also elevated in other gastrointestinal malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

questions.text: A patient consumed a toxic substance and presented with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol is a toxic substance commonly found in antifreeze. When ingested, it is metabolized into toxic metabolites, including oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds to calcium in the blood, forming calcium oxalate crystals, which leads to hypocalcemia—a significant clue in diagnosing ethylene glycol poisoning. Additionally, ethylene glycol poisoning often presents with symptoms like tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension, as seen in this case.

 

Hypocalcemia is a critical diagnostic feature because it specifically points toward ethylene glycol ingestion compared to other toxic substances. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent severe complications, including kidney failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron poisoning typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain) and systemic toxicity such as metabolic acidosis. Hypocalcemia is not a hallmark feature of iron poisoning, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning can cause metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances ("snowfield" vision), and central nervous system depression. Hypocalcemia is not commonly associated with methanol toxicity, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity commonly presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, visual changes, and arrhythmias. While it can cause hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia is not a feature of digoxin poisoning, eliminating this option as the Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by hypocalcemia due to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals and presents with symptoms such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension.

questions.text: Match the following: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SVC - Superior Vena Cava: The structure marked as A is identified as the superior vena cava, which is located on the right side of the chest

 

Option B. Aorta: The structure labeled as B is the arch of the aorta, which appears as a large circular structure in the middle of the chest.

 

Option C. Trachea: The air-filled black structure identified as C is the trachea, which appears as a circular, air-filled structure in the middle of the chest on a CT scan.

 

Option D. Esophagus: The structure marked D is the esophagus, which lies posterior to the trachea and appears as a smaller circular structure on the scan.

 

The correct matching based on the image is option B: A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying structures on a chest CT, it's crucial to accurately recognize the anatomical positions of key structures like the superior vena cava, aorta, trachea, and esophagus based on their appearance and location in cross-sectional imaging.

choices.text: Most common site of impaction is at the level of cricopharyngeus
One of the constrictions of the esophagus is at the level of the right bronchus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding an esophageal foreign body? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common site of impaction is at the level of cricopharyngeus

 

The esophagus has several anatomical constrictions where foreign bodies are prone to become lodged. The most common site for impaction in the context of esophageal foreign bodies, particularly in children who have swallowed objects such as coins, is at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. This muscle is located at the entrance of the esophagus and acts as a physiological sphincter. The location's significance is highlighted by the commonality of impactions here, which often require medical intervention for removal to prevent complications such as perforation or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impaction can not cause mediastinitis: This statement is incorrect. If a foreign body causes esophageal perforation, it can indeed lead to mediastinitis, a severe infection of the mediastinum.

 

Option B. More commonly seen in adults: This is incorrect as esophageal foreign bodies are more commonly seen in children, although they can also occur in adults, especially those with predisposing factors like strictures or motility disorders.

 

Option D. One of the constrictions of the esophagus is at the level of the right bronchus: While this statement is partially true, it refers to a physiological constriction caused by external compression of the esophagus by the right bronchus. However, it is not the primary site for impaction compared to the cricopharyngeus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for esophageal foreign body impaction is at the level of the cricopharyngeus. Understanding the anatomical constriction points of the esophagus is crucial for diagnosing and managing esophageal impactions effectively.

choices.text: The procedure exposed the physician to legal action for battery.
The hysterectomy was justified under emergency doctrine, thus shielding the physician from liability.
Consent for the hysterectomy should have been obtained during labor.
Post-operative counseling of the patient and family about the procedure was unnecessary.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G3P2L2, in active labor with arrested cervical dilation at 8 cm, underwent an emergency cesarean section. The newborn was healthy, but the mother developed severe postpartum hemorrhage unresponsive to conservative measures. An emergency hysterectomy was performed as a life-saving intervention. What is the legal justification for performing this procedure without explicit consent from the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The hysterectomy was justified under emergency doctrine, thus shielding the physician from liability.

 

In cases of acute medical emergencies where a delay in treatment could result in harm or death, obtaining informed consent may not be feasible or legally required. This scenario applied to the patient who suffered intractable postpartum hemorrhage after childbirth, where conservative treatments failed. According to BNS Section 30 (IPC 92), medical interventions necessary to save a life or prevent serious harm can be lawfully performed without consent. This legal protection applies when it's impossible for the patient to give consent or when obtaining consent would jeopardize the patient's health due to time constraints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is incorrect because emergency medical interventions necessary to save a life or prevent serious harm, like the emergency hysterectomy in this case, are legally protected actions even without the patient's explicit consent.

 

Option C: Incorrect, as obtaining explicit consent for emergency procedures during life-threatening situations is not required under the law if it could delay necessary medical intervention.

 

Option D: Counseling post-operation remains an ethical obligation but does not bear legal implications regarding the justification for emergency procedures. The primary issue was the legal justification for the surgery without prior consent, not the postoperative communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emergency situations where a delay in treatment could result in significant harm or death, such as intractable postpartum hemorrhage, the law permits life-saving interventions without prior consent under the doctrine of necessity, as stipulated in BNS Section 30 (IPC 92).

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient has been experiencing recurrent lower lip swelling for six months, presenting as a soft, translucent cystic lesion, as depicted in the provided image. What is the most appropriate diagnosis and management for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucous retention cyst; Surgical excision

 

The patient's symptoms and the appearance of the lesion in the image are indicative of a mucous retention cyst, which typically arises from the obstruction of salivary gland ducts, leading to the formation of a cyst filled with mucus or fragments of a sialolith. Surgical excision is the recommended treatment to remove the cyst entirely and prevent recurrence, as these cysts often do not resolve spontaneously and may recur if not completely excised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because plunging ranulas are a type of retention cyst originating from the sublingual gland and usually present with both intraoral and cervical swelling, which is not evident in this case. Diagnosis often requires imaging such as ultrasound or MRI, and treatment involves more complex procedures such as gland excision and aspiration.

 

 

Option C: Incorrect as oral ranulas present primarily in the floor of the mouth, not the lip, and are managed by marsupialization or excision, depending on their size and recurrence pattern.

 

 

Option D: Incorrect because mucoceles, resulting from salivary gland duct obstruction, typically require more definitive treatments than aspiration alone, which does not address the root cause of the obstruction and is associated with high recurrence rates.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucous retention cysts in the lip should be managed by surgical excision to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence, as they result from the obstruction of minor salivary gland ducts and do not typically resolve spontaneously.
